title: what eu customs union brexit
story: They demanded that the EU replace the backstop - which aims to avoid customs checks on the island of Ireland after Brexit — with alternative arrangements.The European customs union is an agreement between  member states to trade goods more easily.Paperwork and goods checks are reduced when goods cross borders of these countries.It is agreed that there is no tarf to be paid on goods traded within the EU.Trade deals with countries outside of the EU are agreed upon collectively and tarfs on goods exchanged with these countries are the same for each EU member country.If the UK leaves the EU via a Soft Brexit we will still remain in both the single market and the customs union, avoiding disruption to trade.A Hard Brexit meanwhile would involve the UK leaving the single market and customs union, with a loose trade agreement with the EU.As a deal has not yet been decided upon, we may leave the EU with a backstop, the insurance policy in the withdrawal deal, designed to ensure there is no hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republica broader trade deal cannot be agreed.A backstop would keep the UK in the customs union.Being a member of a customs union drastically reduces the amount of time it takes for goods to enter and leave the UK.It also saves money on goods traded between the  EU member countries.Leaving the customs union could disrupt trade, leaving the country without essential goods and potentially causing a loss of jobs.The UK would be able to strike new trade deals with countries outside of the EUit leaves the EU customs union.It could also open new lines of trade, opening up new job opportunities.It is pretty much impossible for the UK to leave the customs union without creating a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland - otherwise this border could become a backdoor for trading.The European Unions single market is a trade agreement between all EU member states which allows free movement of goods, services, capital and people from one EU member country to another.This is why there is no limit on the number of EU migrants who can come to the UK or the number of Brits who can live in Spain, for example.The single market also eliminates tarfs or taxes on trade and has loads of rules and regulations on packaging, safety and standards that apply across the area.It encompasses the EUs  member states as well as the exceptions Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, and Switzerland.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chavez socialist experiment venezuela opinion
story: GDP growth will stall. Taxes will rise. We’ll even run out of Mars bars.But across the Atlantic, something has been ­happening that should give us all some perspective.Over the past decade, Venezuela has plunged into the abyss — but there’s been no civil war, no earthquakes or hurricanes.Just a brutal, corrupt government that has turned what was once Latin America’s richest country into a hellhole.Starvation rations plunged millions into hunger and ­malnutrition, with some resorting to eating dogs, cats, even zoo animals.People got into kne fights over the right to scavenge from a dumpster.Its economy is more than three times smaller than in . Inflation climbed into the thousands, then millions of per cent.The result has been a refugee crisis on the scale of the Syria conflict.No wonder tens of ­thousands of people took to the streets of the capital Caracas this week, declaring national assembly head Juan Guaido the legitimate president.All this is awful for the poor bloody Venezuelans.But what does it have to do with Britain The answer is that Venezuela wasn’t just a ­disaster. It was an experiment — cheered on by Jeremy Corbyn and his cronies.In , Hugo Chavez took over Venezuela.He ruled until his death in , when he was succeeded by his hand-picked protege Nicolas Maduro.Chavez modelled himself on Latin American ­revolutionaries like Fidel Castro and Simon Boli. He nationalised much of the oil industry — which dominates the ­Venezuelan economy — and imposed punitive taxes on foreign firms.He introduced price controls and later currency controls. He declared “economic war” on the “stateless ­bourgeoisie” and seized the goods of private companies he denounced as saboteurs.For Corbyn, the Chavez regime was an inspiration — a chance to see true socialism brought to le.Venezuela, Corbyn has said, “showed us that there is a dferent, and a better, way of doing things. It’s called socialism”.It wasn’t just Corbyn. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell, Shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott and Corbyn’s media chief Seumas Milne have all praised the ­Venezuelan revolution.That “better way of doing things” has ruined tens of millions of lives but there has not been a hint of an apology from Corbyn.Normally, the fact that people are taking to the streets to free themselves of a vicious regime would be cheered to the rafters by the Left.Instead, there is the silence of those who find themselves ­hideously embarrassed.The few who are not ­staring at their shoes claim that Venezuela has been the ­victim of an American plot.That Maduro took, in McDonnell’s words, a “wrong turn” from Chavez’s true socialism.That it was all down to a falling oil price.Yes, Maduro took a wrong turn. But that turn was to follow the path laid out by Chavez.From the Soviet Union to Cuba to Venezuela, there is a long and shabby history of British left-wingers acclaiming a workers’ paradise — only to declare, once its ­failure is clear, that it wasn’t really socialist after all.Never mind the millions of lives ruined — let’s have another go!If he became Prime ­Minister, Corbyn might not succeed in turning Britain into Venezuela. But we’d be Caracas to let him try.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: karren brady influencers dont see kids friends cash
story: Weirdly, for those of us who grew up before the internet took off, that’s an actual job now.And who can blame people for ­saying: “‘Yes please” to money for doing not very much But there is something wrongInstagram users aren’t aware the ­celebrities they follow are being paid thousands of pounds — or even hundreds of thousands — to promote the products they are “recommending”.Advertisers know Instagram — which has a BILLION monthly users posting some million photos a day — is an incredibly powerful way of reaching young people.The more followers a star has, the greater their selling power.Kylie Jenner, who has million ­followers, is paid a whopping £, for every sponsored post.Under the  UK Consumer Protection From Unfair Trading regulations, ­celebrities paid to plug products are supposed to make that clear.But there are no simple guidelines.So while some celebs might say “sponsored” or “#ad” on a post, others are less open about it.That is why the Competition  ­Markets Authority conducted an ­investigation.And this week  British celebrities and “influencers” were found to have failed to follow consumer protection guidelines.They include singers Rita Ora and Ellie Goulding, models Alexa Chung and Rosie Huntington-Whiteley and video blogger Zoella.While all agreed to change their ways, none was taken to court where they might have faced fines or even jail time.“Influencers” might say the clue is in the name. They are paid to inspire you to buy stuff.Most insist they only endorse ­products they actually believe in — and we’d all hope they take their responsibility seriously.But it is easy to see how an offer of, say, £, to endorse something they “sort of” believe in might make it harder to hang on to those principles.Equally,guidelines aren’t strictly enforced, you can understand the temptation to convey the impression that you just happen to really like a particular laxative herbal tea, say, or a moisturiser that gives you a “glow”.It’s a grey area. And you might ask why it matters.But given recent news about the ­negative impact social media can have on the mental health of young people — and young women in particular — regulation of this brave new world affects us all.I need only point to another big story this week.Schoolgirl Molly Russell was  when she took her own le after showing “no obvious signs” of severe mental health issues.Her family later found she had been viewing material on social media linked to anxiety, depression, self-harm and suicide.Her father even went as far as accusing Instagram of “helping to kill her”.Social media makes it so easy to tap into someone’s daily le, their home-decor proclivities and their innermost thoughts.The intimate nature of Instagram lets you feel like these influencers are your friends, and the products they rave about their personal ­recommendations, not the outcome of a business deal.This is a real problem. But the mistake is much harder to makeadverts are clearly labelled as such.Part of the problem is how obsessed with celebrities our young people have become.When I was growing up, my main influenceswere my parents and my friends.Now, young people are influenced by people they will never meet.Some of these people, dare I say it, are talentless nobodies.You might argue you would have to be naive not to realise they are selling you something.Perhaps young people are not as cynical as the likes of me.And that is why regulation is key.IT’S hard to sympathise with Fungi, a “star” of hit telly documentary Benefits Street, who says universal credit is “the worst thing in the world”.Tracked down by this paper, James Clarkeclaimed his monthly payments had been more than halved and the all-in-one benefit was causing “hell” for him and others like him . . . because their booze budget has been cut.Fungi was claiming £ a month to spend on food and sundries. But this was slashed to £ – which doesn’t cover the £ a month he and his partner spend on strong cider.His rent, meanwhile, is paid in full via a separate taxpayer-funded handout.Fungi also says his drinking habit means he can’t work. Sorry, what Here’s another way of looking at it. People who work for eight hours a day don’t have the time to down three litres of cider a day.If Mr Clarke got a job, he might recover some of his self-esteem – and probably save his le in the process.Just to be clear – I BELIEVE in the benefits system.But it was invented to help people get back on their feet, to help those who can’t help themselves because of illness or disability.It should be a short-term measure, not a lestyle choice.In the meantime, the rest of us go to work to pay for this man’s rent and booze.All because he can’t be bothered to sort himself out.No wonder people get angry.In fact, I suspect most readers will have steam coming out of their ears.This man must start taking responsibility for himself.I SUPPOSE it was worth a shot for Diane Abbott to complain that Fiona Bruce was “badly briefed” and that her treatment as a list on Question Time was racist.But she can’t blame Fiona for her own incompetence in answering questions – and not just on Question Time.There are so many car-crash interviews to choose from . . . although the one in which Diane suggested police officers could be paid £ a year springs to mind.WHAT a nasty piece of work Dancing On Ice judge Jason Gardiner seems.We expect the judges to give feedback.And we know it won’t all be good.But his comment to Gemma Collins last week – “We are not going to see big lts from you” – came across as body-shaming.Because his real point is that she is overweight, right It’s shocking, really. I’m surprised ITV allowed it.THE secret behind Elle Macpherson’s phenomenal bod has been revealed.In an interview, she said it all comes down to . . . late breakfasts.Hmmm. No matter when we eat breakfast, most of us will never come close to looking how she does at .Actually, forget breakfast times. What struck me is her diet seems to contain just FIVE ingredients . . . one of which is nut cheese.And the only liquid is water.Elle looks great.But by God, she must be miserable.THE Premier League’s popularity continues to soar, as a study into attendances across Europe proves.And I was immensely proud to see West Ham ranked seventh by attendance in all of Europe last year.We are up there with the Continent’s elite, in a table headed by Barcelona.And that will only get better now the capacity of the London Stadium is up to , – adding to the incredible support we get from what I believe are the league’s best fans.This week, accountancy firm EY published a report on the impact the Premier League has on our economy.It generates £.billion a year in tax for the Exchequer, supporting , jobs and contributing £.billion overall to the country’s GDP.Last season, Premier League players paid more than £billion in taxes.But never mind the money.It’s still the best league in the world.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no delaying halting brexit john mann
story: Across the country people who voted dferent ways in the Brexit referendum are ­becoming bored and irritated by the silly games at Westminster.The truth is that a large majority of MPs are Remainers in their hearts and souls and are struggling to bring themselves to recognise the reality of the situation.It was us MPs who voted to give you, the people, the say on leaving or remaining in the European Union.And you voted, in higher numbers than you have ever bothered voting for any of us. Yet the same MPs who gave you a say are coming up with every excuse for why your views should not be listened to.Of course there are Remainer MPs whose constituencies voted heavily to remain.There are MPs with, I have to say it, courage, who have always argued strongly in a way that they have always known is dferent to their ­voters. These people are ­consistent and have my respect.But there are just as many who are in danger now of sitting on the fence until rigor mortis sets in, coming up with process rather than substance.They are simply hoping that others will do the dirty deed and respect the will of the people.It is also, for every Labour and Conservative MP, the manesto ­promise that we stood on at the last election. We voted for a referendum. We promised to respect the result.We got re-elected promising the same, yet Parliament continues to sit on the roundabout to nowhere.It is time to stop the shenanigans and work across the political ide to bring our country and our people together.At stake is our democracy. And in a democracy the winner prevails.Of course, in future years, people can argue that we have got it wrong and that people are entitled to change their mind. But for democracy to be true and real, we have to deliver the mandate we have been given and leave the EU on March .The referendum ided people and families, with lots of strong and dfering views. But in cherishing our democracy, we now need to come together to deliver a Brexit that respects the people’s vote and helps heal that ide.In le we have to compromise. We all have our own perfect Brexit, me included. And with ten of my colleagues we have forced through a big part of that, guaranteeing in law workers’ rights, health and safety and environmental standards. We will be competing with Europe by being the best, not by being the cheapest.I would love to have been a fly on the wall when Theresa May told union bosses that she was meeting their key demands not just with a promise but with a legal guarantee. But then she knew it was only right, because union members were the bedrock of leave voters across the country.And, I believe, we can get more in the next fortnight. A clear commitment to a once-in-a-generation investment into the Leave-voting areas that have long been starved of our fair shares — those former coal, iron and steel industrial heartlands, the unfashionable places, the areas still manufacturing. I think, as well, that union bosses and industrialists can be brought to act as advisers to the trade negotiations when we have left the EU, bringing their expertise into play to ensure a jobs-first Brexit for Britain.A country, proud and independent, standing on its own two feet, ­confident again in our democracy, bold enough to compete by being the best, British workers making high- quality products and delivering high-quality services.A country that says it will be the best by having better pay, conditions and a healthier environment than anyone  in Europe or worldwide.Is that not something to be confident in voting for, my fellow MPs  Let’s get on with it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cult of brexit remainer fading
story: I will try, but it is hard to see eye to eye with those who regard the .million who voted Out in  as pig- ignorant racists.Or to forgive Chancellor Phil Hammond for twisting Treasury data to undermine the British economy.I will simply wish him well in retirement at the earliest possible moment.Anna Soubry is a bit of a challenge too, but I will ­eventually find something nice to say.As for EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier, even Her ­Eurosceptic Majesty would find little common ground with the man who vowed to punish her United Kingdom for daring to leave.But it will be cult-like Remainers who find it hardest to kiss and make up.Their hatred of Leavers has reached sectarian proportions.Astonishingly a poll found many would ban marriage outside the EU faith.Indeed, my old friendMatthew Parris insists Her Maj was wrong to suggest there is any common ground at all, because it might appear to endorse Theresa May’s dodgy deal.The Times sage has abandoned the Zen-like equilibrium which once made him ­compulsive reading. Along with the likes of megabucks Remainers Tony Blair, Peter Mandelson and PR guru Roland Rudd, he seems to think Brexiters are basically pond le.That theory should be buried forever after this weekend’s passionate plea from leading academic Sir Noel Malcolm for MPs to stop wrecking Brexit.Writing in the devoutly pro-EU Financial Times, this distinguished Fellow of All Souls, Oxford, spells out the essence of the Leave case: “Brexit is about sovereignty — and parliament must respect that.”“If the UK is now on the brink of a constitutional crisis,” he adds, “one major reason is that a signicant number of MPs still oppose any version of Brexit, and seek a second ­referendum solely for the sake of reversing the decision of the last one.”Sir Noel does not believe people voted Out because they were racist.“The most important reason was democracy,” he says.“They wanted to live under laws made by the people they elected. Immigration came second.What they objected to was a supranational government ­making some of their laws and lting all immigration controls on the inhabitants of  other countries.”Another Remainer fiction is that Brexiters are narrow-minded Little Englanders.Yet the Daily Mail found space for a German view that Brussels should stop “insulting Britain” and honour us as champions of peace in Europe.“Such blinkered and sour responses are wrong-headed,” says Alexander von Schoenburg, a senior editor of Germany’s biggest newspaper, Bild.“They ignore the great debt Germany and the whole ­Continent owes our friends across the Channel.“We must always remember that throughout your history, independence and sovereignty have been paramount.“Germany in particular should tread lightly when it comes to dealing with your proud nation. It was Great Britain that first stood up to Hitler in .And it was Britain that opened its doors to thousands of ­Jewish refugees fleeing certain death during the Holocaust.“Put simply, there would be no free Europe without you and the bloody sacrice you made to rescue the Continent.”This remarkable tribute ­follows a recent love letter to the UK from Germany’s next Chancellor calling for a friendly Brexit orce and an end to bitterness.It is now clear hardline Remainers have over-reached themselves. The worm has turned.Talk of a second referendum is dead and voters are on the warpath against MPs plotting to scupper Brexit in tomorrow’s Commons showdown.Brussels is in chaos over the Northern Ireland backstop.Michel Barnier has started muttering about new tech- nology to police post-Brexit ­frontiers — a UK idea initially dismissed as “magical thinking”.EU allies are breaking ranks to demand a decent deal — for their sake as much as ours.It is way past time now for Theresa May to scrap the backstop and tell Brussels exactly what she needs to get her deal through Parliament.“There is absolutely no truth in speculation that ­passengers are being advised not to book,” stormed Brittany Ferries as it announced plans to INCREASE services.Meanwhile, mischief-making aviation giant Airbus admits it was asked by Downing Street to warn – incredibly – that it would shut up shopBritain left without a deal.Project Fear is shameless.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: molly russell social media blame

title: this morning nta ally ross tv opinion
story: Six days a week now, This Morning hammers home the message its viewers are the most helpless, mollycoddled invertebrates on the planet.A form of le so useless that last November Dr Chris Steele, the show’s resident quack, genuinely felt the need to give us all bottom-wiping advice.“It’s a front-to-back action for women,” more of a hit-and-hope exercise for men.Infor this constant nannying, we pick up a phone once a year and gurgle: “You’re absolutely right. We are useless. Have a trophy.”And it’s a depressing cycle that will continue for as long as there are National Television Awards, live from The O.A ceremony where the categories may chop and change every year, but the stupidity remains ritualised.As well as getting all the usual winners though, viewers also had to endure a technical nightmare on Tuesday, where things went wrong — from the shambolic opening scenes right through to the unedited version of the closing credits: “With thanks to — Television Centre White City or just Television Centretoo long.”It’s always a case of fine margins, of course, at the NTAs, and the evening might have strayed into so-bad-it’s-good territorythe cameras had just focused on one of the Love Island gang when host Dermot O’Leary said: “Danny DeVito will be in Dumbo next year.”They didn’t, though. So a night bedevilled by sound issues, rotten acceptance speeches and foul Danny Dyer language was crowned by Special Recognition winner David Dimbleby eulogising the BBC and ordering us to be nicer to politicians, in a speech that could hardly be descri- bed as “mood capturing”.It’s the awards themselves though, that I know get viewers’ goats the most, starting, painful as it is to admit, with the fact perennial winners This Morning absolutely robbed Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain operation in the Daytime category.Given that Jack Whitehall’s Travels With My Father managed to scrape on to the Comedy shortlist, there’s also an argument that says Chunk, Charlotte Hawkins, Richard Arnold and Susanna Reid — who was styled quite magnicently on the night as Waitrose’s answer to Vicky Pattison — should have made that final five as well.Because almost no show made me laugh as loud or as regularly as Good Morning Britain did in .A glaring omission too in the TV Judge section — always won by David Walliams — which included X Factor’s Robbie Williams on the shortlist, but not Craig Revel Horwood, who didn’t take a two-week sabbatical in the middle of Strictly, cost the BBC £million or throw in his other half as part of the deal.The award that made a nonsense of the whole occasion though was Ant  Dec winning Best Presenters for the th time in a row, despite the presence of Bradley Walsh and Graham Norton on the shortlist, and the fact Ant spent far more weeks in rehab than he did in a TV studio.The mutual affection is touching in one way, of course, but it ultimately does neither them nor the NTAs any good at all and has robbed both of a glorious moment of redemption when they win the  award.Before that foregone conclusion takes place, please stay tuned to This Morning and sit tight until mid-March, when Dr Chris will be along with part II of his bottom-wiping masterclass: Flushing, FLU-SHING.Practially the only programme I watched at the weekend that wasn’t punctuated by uncontrollable sobbing fits from the participants was BBC’s landmark Holocaust documentary The Last Survivors.Men and women who are all in their late eighties and nineties now and understand that time is precious.When you’re a living part of history you also know facts are far more precious than tears.So in the words of the remarkable Anita Lasker-Wallfisch, who avoided the Auschwitz gas chamber purely because she could play the cello: “I won’t give people the pleasure of seeing my emotions.”The very least we owe all of them is an audience. The Last Survivors is available on the BBC iPlayer and will probably be the most unforgettable  minutes of television you’ll watch all year.At approximately : hours, Sunday, Gemma Collins stumbled over while Dancing On Ice.The tectonic plates groaned a little on impact, the front row scattered like ten pins and there was a surge on the national grid as several million viewers went “click, rewind, play,” then “click, rewind, play,” again.In fact, by the time I’d stopped rewinding and playing, Gemma had “bounced back,”and Piers Morgan, no doubt angling for a Le Stories interview, had claimed it was “the gutsiest thing I’ve seen on a talent show” – probably since the days Piers himself was wedged in behind the judges’ desk on Britain’s Got Talent.It was an undeniably great television moment, though.A proper face plant, with a full Klinsmann snow plough to finish.The downside, obviously, is that it’s guaranteed she’ll be back next week, when Melody, Wes, James and the others will be performing to a Fairytale theme and Gemma will be clearing the B Fettercairn to Banchory road,ITV want to find a proper use for her.Click, rewind, play.Things remain cheerful as hell on EastEnders.Alfie Moon’s car has been discovered near some clfs and a policeman has the job of breaking the most awful news imaginable to Kat and the Slaters.“Considering the location and the evidence at hand, we would suggest you prepare yourself for the worst.”Big Mo: “You understand what they’re saying ”Yes, bloody Redwater’s getting a second series. Stay strong, viewers.Celebrity Coach Trip, Roxanne Pallett: “I knew as soon as Jedward got on the coach it was going to be fun.”The One Show, Matt Baker: “If you haven’t seen The Greatest Dancer yet, watch it on the iPlayer. It’s well worth it.”And Icons, Kathleen Turner: “Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and smash social barriers.”No, Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and make people laugh.Tell the BBC to try it some time.Good Morning Britain, Piers Morgan: “Every cloud. We lost the NTA, but I got a kiss off Gemma Collins.” Yeah, every cloud’s got a gigantic p***-storm.No one from Peaky Blinders bothering to turn up to the NTAs to thank: “The best fans a show could hope for.”Celebrity Coach Trip contestants Jedward ­providing the finest argument yet for theof a hard Irish border.Sheridan Smith’s accent doing the London to Doncaster trip in . seconds flat, on that Cleaning Up tosh.The Greatest Dancer’s pre-performance sob stories straying horribly close to moral blackmail territory.And E fly-on-the-wall moron Vogue Williams asking: “Is Gandhi the Dalai Lama ” in total ­ignorance of this remarkable man’s wisdom, serenity and even his landmark campaign for Dolce  Gabbana’s Light Blue fragrance . . .Martin Keown: “It should be a great spectacle, so sit back, hide behind the sofa and enjoy it.”Phil Thompson: “You never know what’s going to happen and that’s exactly what happened.”And Paul Merson: “If he was at Arsenal doing this, he wouldn’t be doing it.”.This week’s winner is the bellowing great Orca herself, Gemma Collins, and Sugar, from Total Drama Island.Sent in by Rich, of Lincolnshire. Picture research: Alfie Snelling.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “At the  Olympics, what birds were first released as a symbol of peace ” Georgina: “Eagle.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “What is the name of the monument in Trafalgar Square built in ­honour of Admiral Horatio Nelson ”Gemma: “Pass.”Ben Shephard: “Which British comedian ­presented the television programme Backchat with his father Michael ”Linda: “Jasper Carrott.”And Ben Shephard: “The Tartan Army is the nickname for fans of which national football team ” Najam: “Newcastle United.”Najam. A word . . .ITV’s The Paras: Men Of War, evenit needed three more episodes and better editing.BBC’s The Last Survivors. Tom Jones singing Cry To Me, with the talented Bethzienna Williams, on The Voice.The sudden, joyful NTA realisation the old bald bloke with the white beard in row A was Tim Lovejoy.And Celebrity Coach Trip guide Brendan Sheerin telling Jedward, Charlotte Crosby, Roxanne Pallett et al: “Today, you’re all going to a donkey sanctuary.” Well it’s about time.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nick timothy brady brexit vote
story: With the deadlock among MPs still not broken, nobody knows for sure what will happen.Theresa May says Brexit must go ahead on time. But she also says Britain will not leave the EU without a deal.And her deal — the only one on the table at this late stage — was defeated in the House of Commons by a record majority just two weeks ago.Tonight’s Brexit votes are not quite the final shoot-out between the dferent factions in Parliament. The Government has promised that MPs will vote soon on a new plan.Remainers and soft Brexit supporters in government are pushing to hold that vote as soon as possible.And MPs — backed by a Speaker who will rewrite any Commons rules to soften or stop Brexit — will force more votes on what happens next.Nevertheless, tonight’s votes do matter.One proposal comes from Yvette Cooper, a Labour MP.Her Yorkshire constituents voted to leave the EU by more than two to one and, during the election, she promised them she would “not vote to block Brexit.”Yet that is what her plan does:     MPs vote for her   amendment, they will be able to stop Brexit happening this year.Cooper has the support of several rebel Tories, soJeremy Corbyn whips his MPs to vote for it, she stands a good chance of getting her way.Caroline Spelman and Jack Dromey, Conservative and Labour, have an amendment that calls on the Government to avoid a no-deal Brexit.Dominic Grieve wants MPs to control the Commons timetable, allowing Parliament to vote on dferent ways of watering Brexit down.Labour want to present MPs with options that include, predictably, a second referendum.Despite drafting a manesto saying “Labour accepts the referendum result”, the Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer says in a second referendum he would campaign to overturn the result of the first.It is possible that none of these amendments might pass.Remainers and soft Brexiteers are ided about what should happen.Some want to delay Brexit, some want to tie us to European rules and regulations, and others want another referendum to stop it altogether.Evenno proposal wins a Commons majority, the votes cast by MPs will probably demonstrate that there is a majority to water down Brexit one way or another.For Brexit supporters, this is very dangerous indeed.Some believe they simply need to run down the clock and, in  days, we can leave without a deal.For Leavers who want a negotiated departure, this feels like a serious risk.But Leavers who favour no deal need to ask themselves, can they really be so sure they will get what they want With several Cabinet ministers, many more junior ministers and a Commons majority against no deal, it seems increasingly likely that MPs will ultimately find a way of stopping no deal.When they do, Brexit will only get softer and softer.This is why the amendment proposed by Graham Brady, a senior Conservative, is so important.His idea is to approve the Prime Minister’s original Brexit deal, but with the “backstop” removed.The backstop is hated by unionists, because to prevent barriers to trade between Ireland and Northern Ireland, it creates new barriers to trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.And it is hated by Leavers, because it ties the UK to the EU’s customs union, and Northern Ireland to EU single market rules.Brady wants MPs to vote simply for “alternative arrangements” to the backstop.By avoiding a specic proposal, he hopes the amendment can win a Commons majority and, in doing so, demonstrate to Brussels that the deal they struck with Theresa May can be ratied — but only without the backstop.Critics, largely Remainers, say this is impossible.But in the past week or so, Angela Merkel has questioned whether the backstop is such a good idea after all.The Polish foreign minister has suggested it should expire after five years. And the European Commission effectively conceded that in the event of no deal, they would use policy and technology to prevent a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.In other words, they proposed solutions they once dismissed as “unicorns” and “magical thinking” when they were suggested by the British — and which could render the backstop unnecessary.But this is not all. Some European officials have floated, in private, a more inventive solution: that the UK and Ireland should form a British Isles customs zone, with Britain compensating Ireland for any new friction in their trade with Europe.So it is clear: whatever Remainers claim, alternatives to the backstop are technically and politically feasible.Recognising this, the Brady amendment would give the Government one last chance to negotiate something better.Yet Tory Brexiteers say they might not vote for it. They fear the ambiguity of “alternative arrangements” could allow ministers to negotiate an even worse deal, perhaps tying the whole of the UK to the EU’s customs union and single market rules for good.They do not trust May, her advisers, or most of her Cabinet and demand a specic time limit on the backstop.Butthey vote down the Brady amendment, they will not get what they want, and are more likely to get what they fear.As the clock ticks on and bottoms get even squeakier, MPs will coalesce around a plan to stop a no-deal Brexit.The EU will have no reason to compromise, and Parliament will soften our departure by aligning us with more and more European laws.If Leavers vote against Brady, they will be shooting themselves not in one foot, and not even in both feet, but in the head.As the Commons debates the proposals today, Leavers need to start compromising with reality. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: john mcdonnell blasted for backing venezuelan nicolas maduro
story: The shadow chancellor was lashed by his own MPs and the Government for signing a controversial letter condemning the US for demanding the tyrant step down and hand over power to Juan Guaidó, who leads the newly elected National Assembly.Labour frontbenchers Richard Burgon and Diane Abbott also signed the letter condemning America’s ‘attempt at regime change’.Responding to an urgent parliamentary question on Venezuela, Foreign Office Minister Alan Duncan accused Mr McDonnell of sympathising with a regime which has sent millions into destitution.He said: “So let the signatories of that letter in thebe pinned on every wall as a list of signatures of shame.”Labour MP Mike Gapes slammed the ‘weasel words’ of ‘assorted Stalinist, Trotskyists, anti-Semites - and also members of Labour’s frontbench’ who signed it.Chris Leslie, a Labour former minister, tore into Maduro’s “corrupt communism” before saying: “Wouldn’t it be betterthose who have been hailing that discredited ideology would take this opportunity to apologise and admit they were wrong ”Britain has joined the US, France and other allies in saying they will recognise Mr Guaidó as president in days unless new free and fair elections are called.But Jeremy Corbyn and Mr McDonnell are long-time allies of the Maduro regime and have condemned what they describe as outside interference in Venezuela.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: house graveyard garden spooks buyers price
story: Buyers have been spooked by more than  old headstones and tombs covering the front lawn of the three-bedroom house at North Lopham near Diss, Norfolk.The price of the Grade Two listed home has been slashed by more than £, to £, since it first went on the market last April.The house, which dates back to , was a chapel until it closed in  due to its dwindling congregation.It was snapped up by a property developer and has now been beautully converted into a trendy home with a ft by ft open plan double height living room and kitchen.Estate agents Bedfords are now hoping that buyers will overcome their fears about the graves and snap it up at its cut price.Emmerson Dutton, a partner at Bedfords office in Bury St Edmunds office, said: “I am sure that the gravestones have been a factor in putting off some buyers.“It is a very stylish property, but the activity levels around it have certainly been lower than we would expect.“I think the people who are concerned about the graves don’t go as far as asking for a viewing. We are not trying to hide the gravestones away so the details clearly show them.“But although the house still has the original two doors at the front, the main entrance is at the back via a driveway on the side.“It means that people don’t have to walk down the path between the graves into the house.“Also when you are inside the house, you are not really overlooking the graves because of the layout inside.“I am hoping that perhaps it might appeal to someone from outside the area.”Mr Dutton said the chapel had been bought and turned into a high-quality home with “a wonderful light-filled interior” by a local developer.The developer originally planned to live there before changing his mind and putting it on the market as he wanted to move nearer his childrens’ schools.It was originally up for sale at £, with a dferent agent before it was taken on by Bedfords, who cut the price to £, before cutting it again.Mr Dutton believes the house, which has a new roof and windows, is worth at least £, more than its price tag due to the quality of the conversion.He said: “It just seems buyers are put off which is such a shame as the cost of the conversion far outweighs the price it’s for sale for.“Someone is going to get a real bargain. It might be that once a year, on Halloween, it becomes an issue but most people could live with that.”It has , square feet of living space and underfloor heating with a castellated side extension still bearing the name “Wesleyan Day School.”The graveyard at the front is still owned by the church authorities on a -year lease, meaning they are responsible for its upkeep.Among the graves is a headstone belonging to Jon Cousins, a minister of a Methodist chapel in Diss who died  in .The master bedroom with an en suite bathroom is on the ground floor along with two further bedrooms, a utility room, and family bathroom.Downstairs is a kitchen with oak flooring and state of the art cabinets, an island, granite worktops and a range-style oven.The first floor has a galleried landing around three sides of the building which Bedfords say could be used as a playroom, study areas or hobby space.There is also plenty of built-in storage space and a good-sized garden at the rear with a double cart lodge.

title: mutant blue eyed coyotes california breeding pet dogs
story: The one-in-a-million predators have been spotted by experts prowling near the cities of Sacramento and Santa Cruz.The fact the five animals have not been seen anywhere  on the planet has led experts to deduce they must be a true mutant breed.Scientists say a mutation to the genes which control eye colour likely happened several generations ago, leading to the resulting blue-eyed breed.While the occurrence of such a mutation is rare, its believed the coyotes relatives must have mated with domestic dogs decades ago.Coyotes and dogs can interbreed to form coydogs which have signicant changes in coat colour and altered facial structure and proportions.However, Stan Gehrt, a wildle ecologist at Ohio State University told National Geographic he has never seen the change in eye colour before.Millions of years of evolution has led to all other coyotes having the same golden-brown eyes.“They have the colour which is best for their environments and their way of living,” says Juan Negro, a scientist with expertise in animal eye hue.Which means the blue eyes are probably a huge disadvantage to the coyotes leading to problems with camouflage and light sensitivity.However, according to the photographers, all five observed blue-eyed coyotes appear to be healthy and hunting successfully, meaning the gene may be here to stay. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen hiring butler buckingham palace
story: The successful trainee butler will be based at Buckingham Palace, but be able to travel to other Royal residences such as Balmoral.And the new budding butler must be able to work to a consistently high standard.Accommodation is provided at the palace, though there will be a salary adjustment.The advert on the Royal website says the job will pay £,.-a-year plus benefits.An expert says: By joining our well-established career pathway, we will help you become an all-round hospitality expert. Learning from our experienced team, youll deliver a hospitality service to the highest standard.You’ll deliver s of all scales, from official lunches and receptions, to state occasions, providing an exceptional guest experience for all.But its the thorough preparation that ensures success. And so youll learn all the specialist professional skills needed to make sure presentation and delivery is seamless.In an environment where development and training is commonplace, youll grow your skills quickly. Well be with you every step of the way, and after initial training, youll be supported to achieve an accredited Butlering qualication too.And whether you’re based in London or travelling to other locations, youll look forward to whatever challenge comes your way.Previous hospitality experience would be an advantage but is not essential. Were more interested in your proactive approach and ability to tackle new challenges.Most important is that youre an outstanding team player who enjoys working alongside others every day. This, along with a helpful and supportive attitude, will be key.Although we can guide you on how to deliver an exceptional service at a wide range of events, youll already have a polite, friendly and approachable working style, and will be able to communicate with all kinds of people.Youll also have a good attention to accuracy and detail, and get satisfaction from a job well done, delivering work to a consistently high standard.And above all, you’ll be committed to a career in hospitality and keen to develop your professional knowledge.Though the pay is low - ex-Royal butlers with the right pedigree and long service can command more than £,-a-year in the private sector.Applications close on February .

title: gas field decade found north sea scotland british industry boost
story: The Glengorm field, east of Aberdeen, is described as the biggest gas discovery of its kind in a decade.Drilling found the equivalent of around  million barrels of oil could be recovered from the site -  about five per cent of the UKs annual gas demand.The astonishing find has been hailed as signicant by industry experts, who reckon the field could be producing gas within four to five years via existing rigs in the area.Glengorm - discovered by Chinese company CNOOC - is close to energy giant Totals Elgin-Franklin and Culzean fields.The gas is in a reservoir with high pressure and high temperatures, meaning it will be more costly to produce than other gas fields.But Kevin Swann, a senior analyst with the consultancy group Wood Mackenzie, said the scale of the reservoir would make it economically viable to extract.He told the BBC: There is a lot of hype around frontier areas like West of Shetland, where Total discovered the Glendronach field last year. But Glengorm is in the Central North Sea and this find shows there is still le in some of the more mature UK waters.The Oil and Gas Authority branded the discovery “very exciting news”.And Andy Samuel, chief executive of the regulator, said there is every chance of yet more signicant finds”.But environmental groups have slammed the find, saying the venture will contribute to climate change.They want energy firms to leave oil and gas in the ground and use renewable resources.Caroline Rance, from Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: Its a disgrace that oil and gas exploration is still going ahead in the seas off Scotland.Its high time our governments stopped supporting fossil fuel development, and get serious about planning a just transition away from this industry.Energy Minister Paul Wheelhouse said the announcement, highlights the signicant potential for oil and gas which still exists beneath Scotlands waters.He added: Scotlands offshore oil and gas industry has an important role to play with up to  billion barrels of oil equivalent remaining under the North Sea and in the wider basin and discoveries such as this help to support security of supply as we make the transition to a low carbon energy system.

title: penny mordaunt foreign aid target
story: She delivered a presentation to Cabinet colleagues on a detailed plan to tweak rules that would slash the amount taxpayers contribute to the bloated £ billion a year budget.Ms Mordaunt told weekly meeting - chaired by the Prime Minister - that the Government could then use the savings to boost NHS spending and “other domestic priorities”.Cabinet ministers also backed moves to use the foreign aid budget to support Britain’s Armed Forces and humanitarian missions.The strict rules by the OECD’s Development Assistance Committeemean millions of pounds of aid spending do not count towards the . per cent of national income target.Hundreds of millions of our aid spending is spent through private firms - such as the CDC Group.These contractors make profits, which are then invested back into foreign aid projects, but the rules bar these profits from being counted towards the . per cent target.Ms Mordaunt said changing the rules to allow this reinvested profit to count towards the target would free up millions of pounds for other departments by shaving the bloated aid budget.She said this would also allow her Department for International Developmentto “move from being a spending department to a fundraising department”.Ms Mordaunt told Cabinet that the . per cent “in its current form is unsustainable” but changing rules would help the foreign aid obligations become “less reliant” on the public purse.She launched a new consultation with charities, financial services, investors and the public about how to allocate more private money towards the foreign aid target.Ms Mordaunt said the review will also look into how money invested in saving and pension funds could deliver more s for UK investors.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nick clegg job fix facebook molly russell
story: The former Deputy Prime Minister, last seen being booted out by the voters of Sheffield Hallam, has re-emerged as Facebook’s Mr Fixit — the man tasked by its CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, with rescuing the reputation of the embattled internet firm.Having claimed that “I actually find the messianic Calornian new-worldy-touchy-feely culture of Facebook a little grating”, Sir Nick has duly installed himself in a £million mansion near San Francisco, ready to offer his expertise.Some people have been puzzled about why the world’s most powerful social media company, owner of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, would recruit a man whose main brush with online fame was an autotuned video of him apologising for betraying the public over tuition fees.In fact, Clegg and Zuckerberg are a match made in heaven. Both are powered by an inexorable sense of self-righteousness. And both have an awful lot of experience of saying sorry.The most recent example came when Sir Nick appeared on the BBC in the wake of the furore over the death of -year-old Molly Russell.It turned out, after she was found dead in her bedroom in December , that she had been viewing material online relating to depression, self-harm and suicide — material which was shockingly easy to find.As her father Ian Russell put it bluntly: “Instagram helped kill my daughter.”Sir Nick, to his credit, said all the right things about how the firm was determined to do more. But he also made the striking claim that it is sometimes better for Facebook and Instagram to keep suicide images online, because it helps other vulnerable young people get support.This after The Sun, on Saturday, found and flagged up multiple images appearing to normalise and even romanticise suicide, all within a few clicks. Many remained published for days, and a Facebook spokesman claimed they could be beneficial to users battling mental health issues.Sir Nick says the firm is following the advice from leading experts and charities. And it may well be doing the right thing. But this is the latest example of Facebook — and other social media giants in general — only acting to tackle a problem once it becomes impossible not to.Over the past decade, social media has come to dominate our lives. The latest research from Ofcom shows internet use rocketing among children and teenagers, with friendships and social lives increasingly run through screens and phones.And it is now clear that this great move online has been accompanied, for our children, by a staggering increase in mental health problems.The situation is particularly alarming when it comes to young women. The latest NHS data found that one in four of those aged  to  report having a mental health disorder — twice the rate among boys.In  alone, one in five US girls aged between  and  suffered a major depressive episode — one in five! Suicide rates for teenage girls, according to academic Jonathan Haidt, have risen by  per cent in the US and  per cent in the UK in a decade.This isn’t just about what happens on the internet. Those having problems online often tend to be experiencing problems offline too, such as bullying, harassment or broken families.More broadly, Haidt believes the “snowflake” phenomenon reflects that “helicopter parenting” leaves children less prepared to cope with shocks and dficulty. But the internet, and social media, are very clearly intensying those problems. And the big tech firms are still playing catch-up.The traditional argument from Silicon Valley is that it’s not their job to regulate human behaviour. They add that eventhey wanted to, there is simply too much out there.They are doing their best to crack down on inappropriate content, but it’s like trying to stem the tide. Behind the scenes — they insist — thousands of people are working day and night to detect and delete messages promoting terrorism, hatred, Holocaust denial and self-harm.But this argument just doesn’t wash. It’s very clear that, in the interests of their bottom lines, many of the big social media firms have long failed to put enough resources into detecting damaging content.Researchers have shown, for example, how following the recommended links from reputable YouTube content can lead to a carnival of horrors. News reports that segue into crackpot conspiracy theories and videos for toddlers that give way to horrendous scenes of a bloodied Minnie Mouse trapped in an escalator.Every day brings new horror stories, such as rival fans of royals Kate and Meghan using the Kensington Palace Instagram to send death threats to each other. Increasingly, online hate is triggering real-le violence. The slaughter of the Rohingya Muslims in Burma was, The New York Times said, “a genocide incited on Facebook”.Part of the reason that Zuckerberg has hired Clegg is to put his house in order. Clegg has talked the right talk about changing Facebook’s culture, and in particular doing more to tackle self-harm.He even says they might start paying more tax. ButZuckerberg’s answer to “how to fix the internet” is “hire Nick Clegg”, we have still got an awfully long way to go.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says theresa may eu commons victory
story: After a crushing defeat a fortnight ago, she has won a vote sending her back to Brussels with a firm mandate to demand more from the Brexit deal.The EU can stonewall all it likes. title: brexit leave eu march 29 2019 deal chequers theresa may
story: Theresa May is now fighting to stay on top after multiple votes eroded her vision of Brexit. Heres the latest on Britains departure from the EU.Brexit comes from merging the words Britain and exit.The term has been widely used ever since the idea of a referendum on leaving the EU was put forward.More than million people voted in the June  referendum with a turnout of . per cent. Leave won by  per cent to  per cent.People now talk about “soft” and “hard” Brexit in reference to how close the UK will be to the EU post separation.The road to triggering Article  — which saw Britain officially start the process of leaving the EU — was paved with complications for the PM, including a Supreme Court case ruling MPs needed to vote on Brexit negotiations.But it was finally triggered on March , , meaning the official departure date and move into the transition phase is due to take place on March , .The European Union is an economic and political partnership. There are currently  members states including the United Kingdom.It began as a trade group of six nations in the s.The UK first applied to join what was then the European Economic Community in  and finally became a member in .Now called the European Union, it has grown to include former Soviet bloc states and has at its heart a “single market” allowing goods and people to move freely.It has its own parliament, central bank and the euro currency used by  countries, with some members including Britain opting to keep their own money.Eurocrats have been pushing for ever closer political and financial union, which could include a European Army separate from the Nato alliance.Those in favour of leaving said Britain was being held back by EU red tape with too many rules on business.They also campaigned on the issue of sovereignty and said they wanted Britain to take back full control of its borders.Beyond the question of ceasing to be a member of the EU, what Brexit actually means in practice has been the subject of intense debate ever since.Theresa May officially triggered Article  on March ,  after which there was a two-year time limit set for negotiations to hammer out the details.The UK is therefore bound to leave the EU by March , , although there is a -month transition period.Negotiations began on June , with the two chief negotiators, Michel Barnier of the EU and former Brexit Secretary David Davis, immediately setting off to find common ground.Some of the “uncertainties” being discussed include citizens living in each others territory, border arrangements between Ireland and the UK and the amount Britain stands to pay to honour its existing EU commitments.This is a bridging agreement between the current situation – where we are members of the EU – and our long-term relationship outside the bloc.Also known as an implementation phase, it allows for the UK to keep some of the same arrangements with Brussels on trade and other matters until a new comprehensive trade agreement is sealed.In March , Britain secured a transition deal that will also allow ministers to seek trade agreements around the globe.The UK will also be free to set its own foreign policy as soon as Brexit happens, as well as negotiate and sign new trade deals anywhere in the world – to implement them in .However EU chiefs made it clear the period, which allows the UK to stay in the Single Market and Customs Union, will only come into forcethe Irish border is sorted.Former Brexit Secretary David Davis and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier unveiled terms for the  month interim period.The UK will not be fully out of the EU until December ,  – four and a half years after the historic referendum decision.But EU leaders have suggested they could extend the transition period further.Theresa May finally struck a Brexit deal with Brussels on November ,, after days of round-the-clock talks in Brussels.But this has proved just the beginning of a long drawn-out, painful process.Facing near certain defeat by Parliament, which is required to back the deal, Mrs May cancelled the meaningful vote on December .The opposition centred predominantly on the backstop agreement which ensures there is never a border between Northern Ireland and the Republic.The backstop will see Britain remain in the customs union for as long as necessary until an alternative way of keeping the border open is found.May is set to go back to the EU and demand it ditches the hated Northern Ireland backstop in a last ditch plan to save Brexit.It came after the UK parliament backed an amendment instructing the Prime Minister to demand that Brussels replace the backstop — which aims to avoid customs checks on the island of Ireland after Brexit  — with alternative arrangements.

title: what is brexit deal and what happens next
story: We explain what Theresa Mays Brexit deal is and what will happen next.The PM presented her first Brexit deal after getting the backing of the EU at the end of November.Many MPs on both sides of the aisle had slammed the Withdrawal Agreement when it was first presented in the House of Commons.Key points of that deal included:May scrapped the meaningful vote on her deal in the th hour in December.
