title: theresa may remainer prime minister brexit views
story: But does the PM actually want to leave the EU, and did she campaign to stay or go  Heres what we know.In the months before the  Referendum, Theresa May was in the remain camp but was noticeably quiet in her campaigning.As Home Secretary she toed the party line that then PM David Cameron had set out.But the MP for Maidenhead did have moments where she strongly discouraged Brexit, warning voters that a Leave result could have seriously damaging ramications for the economy and security of the UK.Mrs May also said that leaving the EU would be “fatal for the Union with Scotland”, as the Scottish National Party SNP would most likely try again for independenceScotland voted to remain while the UK as a whole voted to leave.But she did say that whatever the outcome Britain should leave the European Court of Human Rights.She highlighted the problems that the ECHR had made for her as Home Secretary, including delaying the extradition of Abu Hamza, nearly stopping the deportation of Abu Qatada, and when the ECHR “tried to tell Parliament that – however we voted – we could not deprive prisoners of the vote”.May did not touch on immigration at all during the campaign - a noticeable omission given her Cabinet role.As Home Secretary, she brought in controversial measures to reduce migration into the UK, including a minimum income requirement.And her Go Home adverts attracted widespread condemnation after critics accused her of spearheading a message of hate around Britain.Brexit means Brexit May is fond of saying, but what does she really think of it After the shock referendum result in June  Theresa May performed a quick turnaround, apparently parking her remain leanings to one side.Within a week of Camerons resignation she had put herself forward for the Tory leadership and was voted in unopposed.As a Remainer, she tried to appeal to both camps, promising the best possible deal was we leave the EU and to make Britain work for everyone.In an apparent bid to keep Brexiteers happy, she appointed some of the most prominent Leave campaigners to key Cabinet roles, including Boris Johnson as Foreign Secretary, David Davis as Brexit Secretary and Liam Fox as International Trade Secretary.But a tough few years have ensued, and Mays first deal agreed by the EU has been slammed by MPs on all sides.Published in November , it contained some key points that have irked critics.After surviving a vote of no confidence in her leadership from her own party in December, she spoke of a renewed mission - delivering the Brexit people voted for, bringing the country back together and building a country that really works for everyone.MPs voted down her Brexit deal  to  votes on January . She then survived a second vote of no confidence in her government by  votes.Mrs May was hellbent on protecting her deal - but its unclear that MPs or EU leaders will budge.These are words she has used time and time again - it remains to be seen whether she can make her vision a reality.On January  she presented plan B of her Brexit deal in House of Commons.She reaffirmed her view that Britain was going to leave the EU and she opposed a second referendum.She told MPs: Our duty is to implement the decision of the first one.I fear a second referendum would set a dficult precedent that could have signicant implications for how we handle referendums in this country.During a vote on January , the UK parliament backed an amendment instructing May to demand that Brussels replace the backstop — which aims to avoid customs checks on the island of Ireland after Brexit  — with alternative arrangements.But the EU signalled they were not willing to budge.Not least, strengthening the hand of those campaigning to break up our United Kingdom.It would require an extension of Article . We would very likely have toa new set of MEPs to the European Parliament in May.And I also believe that there has not yet been enough recognition of the way that a second referendum could damage social cohesion by undermining faith in our democracy.

title: brexit vote house of commons theresa may
story: The Labour boss said he would look forward to talking face to face with the PM after pro-EU plotters LOST their plan to kill off Brexit.Theresa May has been asking him to No to discuss Brexit for weeks, but hes repeatedly turned her down.Tonight the PM successfully fought off a Remainer bid to stop her leading us out of the EU in March - by  votes to .But a separate non-binding bid led by Labours Caroline Spelman to rule out No Deal passed - in a warning to Brexiteers that they would have a tricky time to trying to force Britain to leave with nothing at all.Tonights Cooper plot was widely seen as a thinly veiled scheme to try and turn around our exit altogether and keep us in the bloc against the will of the British public.Peoples Vote campaigners threw their weight behind it, thinking it could allow time for a second referendum.And even Jeremy Corbyn joined the plot by anti-Brexit campaigners tonight - but it still wasnt enough to get it to pass.Today Mr Corbyn revealed he would order all his MPs to support the plan, and claimed ministers have no choice but to delay Brexit for three months.As many as  MPs defied Jeremy Corbyn and either voted against him or abstained tonight - including shadow ministers Melanie Onn and Tracy Brabin.Eight Labour frontbenchers face being sacked for directly going against the Labour boss.In another dramatic night in Westminster:Defeated Yvette Cooper and Nick Boles hinted they would try again to stop a No Deal from happening.We are running out of time. We will consider what amendments will be neededat that point no progress has been made.We remain committed to ensuring that we don’t reach the clf edge on  March without a deal.”Crestfallen Remainer Chuka Umunna said he was deeply disappointed by the losses tonight and said Parliament had been robbed of the chance to stop Brexit.And Lib Dem Layla Moran tore into Labour MPs for abstaining, some of them not even bothering to voting at all.Shame on those members who sat on their hands on the Cooper amendment, she blasted.One MP said that Mr Corbyns dire speech earlier was a key factor in keeping Labour MPs away.But another said that chaos last night over a separate Brexit bill on immigration put them off, saying: Im not risking my seathe cant get his act together.Mr Corbyns own plan for a delay to Brexit and seeking a customs union with the bloc was slapped down resolutely by MPs tonight too.And another plot by chief Remainer Dominic Grieve to give MPs control of the Commons timetable to debate Brexit was also defeated - by  - .Tonight MPs voted to tell Mrs May to go back to Brussels and rip out the hated Northern Ireland backstop - and they COULD get behind her deal.They backed a change by Sir Graham Brady which pushed for alternative arrangements to be secured instead.The law states that after the deals defeat, the PM must make a statement in the Commons announcing her plans - which she did last Monday, saying she would press on with her current deal.The Government must then table a so-called neutral motion to be voted on - stating simply that the House of Commons has considered the statement made by the PM.Why does the vote matter Whether or not MPs vote in favour of the motion tabled by Mrs May is literally meaningless.But crucially, the motion can be amended - giving the Commons the right to pass any resolution it wants and dictate to the Government what it should do next.What are the amendments There are two main amendments - one from Labours Yvette Cooper which rules out a No Deal Brexit, and another from top Tory Graham Brady which kills off the Irish backstop.But another five amendments from across the political spectrum were also selected for a vote by Speaker John Bercow.Most of the amendments arent legally binding but would provide a clear political message to the Government.But the Cooper amendment is legally binding - making it more worrying to ministers than the others.So what next Tonight’s vote is not a rerun of the first meaningful vote on whether or not to approve the Brexit deal.That is likely to come some time in February - whatever happens this evening.The Peoples Vote campaign for a second referendum has publicly supported the move as the first step towards cancelling Brexit altogether.A number of Tory Remainers are expected to vote for the Cooper amendment rather than risk No Deal.Today Business Minister Richard Harrington issued an extraordinary public warning to the PM not to take Britain out of the EU without a deal.He told the BBC: Many of us have been to see the Prime Minister and have told her the absolute catastrophe and disaster for jobs and the economy that No Deal would be.What she has asked us is that we give her another two weeks.Mr Harrington said he would quit as a ministerthe PM refused to give MPs another chance to rule out No Deal within a fortnight.Mrs May is pinning her hopes on a rival amendment from Tory backbench chief Sir Graham Brady.That motion would declare that the Commons supports the PMs deal as long as the Irish backstop is removed.A TOTAL of  dferent amendments were tabled to today’s Brexit motion - and Speaker John Bercow selected seven to go for a vote.COOPER AMENDMENT - DELAY BREXIT Labours Yvette Cooper has teamed up with Tory ex-minister Nick Boles to try to take No Deal off the table.The cross-party amendment would force the Government to introduce a bill giving unprecedented powers to MPs.The House of Commons would have been able to vote to delay Brexit by up to nine monthsBritain is heading towards a No Deal outcome.The bill states thatthere is no deal in place by February , MPs could then instruct the Government to seek an extension of Article , the legal mechanism taking us out of the EU.Jeremy Corbyn backed the amendment today - which gave it a good chance of success - but ultimately it failed when some of his own MPs abandoned him.BRADY AMENDMENT - DROP THE BACKSTOP Sir Graham Brady is one of a group of senior Brexiteers whove tabled an amendment to kill off the Irish backstop.The amendment states that the Commons is prepared to back Theresa Mays deal, but only on condition the backstop is replaced with alternative arrangements to avoid a hard border.Although it wouldnt be binding, Sir Graham says thatit passes it would allow the PM toto Brussels and secure changes to the withdrawal agreement.The Government is supporting the amendment and will tell Tory MPs they must vote for it.GRIEVE AMENDMENT - SEIZING CONTROL Dominic Grieve, the Tory Remainer with a history of tabling wrecking amendments, wants MPs to grab control of the Commons agenda.The Government would have mean the Government lose the power to determine the order of business on six specic days in February and March.Its thought anti-Brexit MPs would have take the opportunity to table legislation which could delay or even scrap our EU departure.SPELMAN AMENDMENT - RULE OUT NO DEAL  The amendment with the most cross-party support was drawn up by senior Tory Caroline Spelman and Labours Jack Dromey.It states that the Commons rejects the United Kingdom leaving the European Union without a withdrawal agreement - but its not legally binding.REEVES AMENDMENT - KEEP US IN Labour MP Rachel Reevess amendment is similar to Yvette Coopers, but is not binding on the Government.It states thatno deal has been reached by February , the Government should ask Brussels to extend the Article  process.This one didnt pass.LABOUR AMENDMENT - FUDGE Jeremy Corbyn tabled an amendment calling for a string of additional votes on what should happen next.The options mentioned include delaying Brexit, staying in a customs union or holding a second referendum.SNP AMENDMENT - LISTEN TO SCOTLAND SNP boss Ian Blackford has proposed a motion concluding thatthe people of Scotland should not be taken out of the EU against their will.The PMs spokesman said: In order to win the support of the House of Commons, legal changes to the backstop will be required. That will mean reopening the withdrawal agreement.The Prime Minister also reiterated that today will not be the last chance for Parliament to express a view on the Brexit process.If we have not brought back a revised deal by February ,  we will make a statement and again table an amendable motion for debate the next day. Parliament will therefore be given time to have its say whatever happens.”

title: theresa may brexit vote house of commons
story: Brexiteer MPs backed the PMs pledge to rewrite the deal she thrashed out with the EU in a last-ditch bid to get it over the line.Pro-Brexit Tories gave Mrs May a leline by backing an amendment tabled by Sir Graham Brady which calls for the Irish backstop to be dropped from the deal.The victory came in a dramatic turnaround just two weeks after her deal looked dead in the water following a humiliating Commons defeat.And in a double boost, the PM saw off an attempt by Labour to legally delay our exit date and rule out No Deal - widely seen as a backdoor bid to block Brexit altogether.The defeat of the motion tabled by Yvette Cooper and backed by Jeremy Corbyn is a huge blow to the so-called peoples vote campaign pushing for a second referendum.But a cross-party amendment speaking out against No Deal did succeed - suggesting that in future MPs could tie Mrs Mays hands on the issueshe fails to win agreement for her deal.And the support of Brexiteers is still uncertain after senior figures warned theyll pull their backingthe PM doesnt secure meaningful changes.Mrs May is now expected to head to the EU capital this week to urge European leaders to reopen talks on the withdrawal agreement.But within minutes of her dramatic victory, top Eurocrat Donald Tusk laid the ground for a huge row by insisting the text of the deal is already fixed.MPs voted in turn on seven dferent amendments each laying out a dferent way forward for Brexit.But the bid to rule out No Deal, tabled by Yvette Cooper, was defeated as up to  Labour MPs defied Jeremy Corbyns order to support it.Instead MPs backed a much weaker amendment from ex-minister Caroline Spelman, which calls on the Government to rule out No Deal but has no legal effect.Four other amendments intended to water down Brexit were all also defeated.But the Brady amendment passed by  votes to  - as seven Labour rebels defied Jeremy Corbyn to vote for it, balancing out the eight Tories who opposed it.Speaking after the end of the voting, Mrs May insisted that No Deal was not off the table but vowed to work with senior MPs across the parties to build support for her deal.She said: Tonight a majority of honourable members have said they would support a deal with changes to the backstop.Combined with measures to address concerns over Parliament’s role in the negotiation of the future relationship and commitments on workers’ rights, in law where need be, it is now clear that there is a route that can secure a substantial and sustainable majority in this house for leaving the EU with a deal.We will now take this mandate forward and seek to obtain legally binding changes to the withdrawal agreement that deal with concerns on the backstop while guaranteeing noto a hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland. My colleagues and I will talk to the EU about how we address the house’s views.As I said this afternoon, there is limited appetite for such a change in the EU and negotiating it will not be easy.But in contrast to a fortnight ago, this house has made it clear what it needs to approve a withdrawal agreement.Now MPs have signalled they want “alternative arrangements” to the hated Northern Ireland backstop, then she can tell the EU thatthey make the change, Parliament is almost certain to sign it off in the coming weeks.Mrs May will speak to EU leaders today and the rest of the week - and could dash to Brussels for emergency talks too to thrash out a compromise.Jean-Claude Juncker has already ruled it out, but the PM could go around him to talk to the heads of the other EU states.If they manage to get a change, she will then give MPs another vote on her deal within weeks.If not, the PM will probably tell her MPs it’s her deal or nothing, having fought with the EU as much as possible but to no avail.MPs who fear crashing out could then turn around at the last minute and back the deal.Responding, Jeremy Corbyn agreed for the first time to attend talks on Brexit at  Downing Street.He said: The Prime Minister must now face the reality that No Deal is not an option. I will meet the Prime Minister and others from across Parliament to find a sensible Brexit solution that works for the whole country.Boris Johnson hailed the PMs victory, saying the result was “clear unambiguous good news” and a “huge victory for Britain”.The Tory big hitter said: “The PM now has a mandate from Parliament that the backstop, the thing that keeps us locked in the single market, the customs union, has to come out.“Parliament has very clearly said there has to be a change. I hope our friends in Brussels will listen and make that change.Odds of the PMs deal getting passed shortened as a delay to Article  became less likely.Opening the debate this afternoon, Mrs May hinted at support for a new Brexit plan dreamed up by an unlikely alliance of Leavers and Remainers from across the Conservative party.The proposal, dubbed the Malthouse compromise after Housing Minister Kit Malthouse, would see an extended transition period designed to avoid chaos even in the event of a No Deal outcome.Mrs May said: While there are obviously details that need to be worked through, the fact that leading figures from dferent sides of the argument are coming together to develop proposals shows how much progress has been made over the past few weeks.Her commitment to fixing the backstop drew praise from top Brexiteers, including Jacob Rees-Mogg who said: May I thank her for her very clear assurances that the withdrawal agreement text will be re-opened and that she will be considering what has been called the Malthouse compromise.The DUPs Nigel Dodds added: She can be assured of our support in trying to find a solution which avoids any hard border on the island of Ireland but also avoids any borders within the UK.A meeting of the hardline European Research Group agreed to back the Brady motion - vice-chairman Steve Baker said: “A vote for the Brady amendment is a vote to seethe PM can land a deal that will work.But arch-Brexiteer Mark Francois warned that Eurosceptics could vote the deal down all over againthe concessions on the backstop aren’t good enough.Mrs May fought fiercely against Yvette Coopers amendment, which would have given MPs the right to delay Brexit by up to nine monthsa deal isnt secured by the end of February.Labour chiefs decided to back the amendment after a meeting this morning - and the Peoples Vote campaign for a second referendum has publicly supported the move as the first step towards cancelling Brexit altogether.But it was defeated by a -vote margin after pro-EU ministers decided to back the Prime Minister.Mrs May vowed to bring a revised deal back to this house for a second meaningful vote as soon as we possibly can, adding thatthe deal hasnt passed by February  MPs will have another chance to declare their favoured solution then.And she mocked Labours shambolic Brexit policy, summarising it as, Lets have a few more votes in the future, possibly, maybe,we think it might be useful, at some stage.The PM concluded: If you want to leave with a deal you have to vote for it. If you want Brexit, you have to vote for Brexit.Before todays debate, Business Minister Richard Harrington issued an extraordinary public warning to Mrs May not to take Britain out of the EU without a deal.After a crushing defeat a fortnight ago, she has won a vote sending her back to Brussels with a firm mandate to demand more from the Brexit deal.The EU can stonewall all it likes. But every binding Remainer motion to impede or delay Brexit was defeated.And there is no point Brussels bleating about the Withdrawal Agreement being set in stone. We know it isn’t. Some EU figures have admitted it isn’t.They could tweak the text, time-limit the backstop or find another solution.They choose not to. And they will stick to that as long as they believe Parliament’s Remainers will ultimately strip the Government of its only negotiating leverage, the threat to just walk away.Remainers, some in Cabinet, may well yet do that. Nonetheless last night should sow doubt in Brussels’ minds.The victorious Brady amendment demands a vital, legally binding change to the Irish backstop before the PM’s deal can pass, just as The Sun called for.Even a dejected Corbyn has conceded he now needs to talk to Mrs May.The PM needs to know precisely what she’s demanding from Brussels — and we’re far from confident the EU will see reason. It is still more likely Brexit will be delayed, softened to a point that could tear the Tories apart or halted.But, after last night’s staggering turnaround, who knows He told the BBC: Many of us have been to see the Prime Minister and have told her the absolute catastrophe and disaster for jobs and the economy that No Deal would be.What she has asked us is that we give her another two weeks.Mr Harrington said he would quit as a ministerthe PM refused to give MPs another chance to rule out No Deal within a fortnight.

title: leavers remainers together uk flourish brexit
story: We all want certainty that we will be leaving the EU on th March.  That would enable us all to plan for le beyond Brexit and lead to a period of political calm.The Government’s deal has been rejected by Parliament.  Therefore, leavers and remainers need to come together to develop a new plan so that we can deliver the referendum result and ensure that we flourish outside the EU.This is exactly what we have tried to do with the help of Kit Malthouse. Nicky Morgan, Robert Buckland and Stephen Hammond were on dferent sides to me and Steve Baker during the referendum.  But we have decided to put our dferences aside and unite to publish a new proposal on how we should leave the EU.Leavers rejected the Government’s EU deal because the backstop would have stopped us from agreeing trade deals. So, we have suggested replacing the backstop with a new protocol that solves the concerns people have about the Irish border and which protects the Union of the United Kingdom.Remainers want a guaranteed Implementation Period – a period which allows us all to adjust to le beyond the EU.  Our plan offers a smooth transition with an additional year of the Implementation Period, making it last until no later than the end of December .Parliament, our country and the  member states of the EU are united in wanting a deal and this proposal can pass through Parliament and restore Government unity, purpose and direction.If the EU ignores this consensus, we have proposed a Plan B – a “triple safety net” to protect us.  It includes cooperation on security, a guarantee by the UK of zero tarfs, no quantitative restrictions and no new trading barriers, along with a generous offer to pay our financial contributions infor an Implementation Period.These proposals would allow everyone to prepare fully for the UK leaving the EU and gives us the space to have proper trade talks so that we can develop a close trading relationship  – which, after all, is what Brexit was supposed to be about.Millions of people voted to leave the EU so that we could become an outward- looking, strong, free-trading nation.They also wanted us to maintain the closest of friendships with our allies on the continent, to continue to trade closely with our European counterparts and to let EU citizens - who have become our friends and neighbours and made the UK their home - feel welcome here.We can still be proud of our shared European heritage after leaving the EU but we must do this as an independent nation.This plan gives us a way of doing this and we invite everyone across the House of Commons and the country to support us as we forge a deal that brings the whole country together.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit theresa crawls back brussels
story: NewsBrexit: Theresa May crawls back to Brussels after caving to Brexiteers to survive Commons showdownBut the EU has already rejected re-opening the withdrawal agreement despite the Commons voteShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorMikey Smith:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video theresa-admits-renegotiation-eu-wont-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May will go crawling back to Brussels to try to reopen the orce deal with the EU after bowing to pressure from Brexiteers. The Prime Minister is planning to beg the EU to rethink the controversial Irish border backstop within days. MPs backed a move to resurrect Mrs May’s deal - for now. But before she had even left British soil EU chief Donald Tusk had rejected her Plan B. “The withdrawal agreement is not open for negotiation,” he said. Even Mrs May conceded there was “limited appetite” for her Plan B in Brussels and warned her backbenchers that negotiating it would not be easy.   But her surrender to the eurosceptic wing of her party dramatically ramped up the threat of the UK crashing out of Europe without a deal. She backed a plan supported by Tory hardliners which could lead to the country leaving on damaging WTO terms, putting workers’ rights at risk. Mrs May supported an amendment tabled by Tory grandee Sir Graham Brady to replace the backstop with “alternative arrangements” to avoid a hard border. Downing Street believes that the plan would give the PM the “ammunition” she needs to go back to Brussels and demand change.   MPs backed the plan  to , majority , to rip up more than two years’ of gruelling negotiations and send her back to Brussels.It raised the astonishing spectre of the PM walking through the lobbies with Tory rebels to effectively vote against her own Brexit deal.Tory whips slapped each others’ backs after the result. But their main focus was on the  Tory MPs who had helped crush the PM’s own Brexit plan two weeks ago, fuelling a record -vote defeat. Last night,  of those Tory rebels backed the Brady plan in the hope it would strengthen the PMs negotiating hand. At the same time, MPs rejected plans to delay Brexit by at least three months to give more time to reach a deal. They voted down an amendment by Labour ’s Yvette Cooper by  to , majority , that would have given them the power to step in and avoid no deal.Instead they backed an amendment by Tory Caroline Spelman to make clear they wanted crashing out taken off the table - but it was not legally binding.After the vote, Jeremy Corbyn revealed he was ready to meet Mrs May – after shunning talks for two weeks.The Labour leader said: “Tonight Parliament has voted to remove the immediate threat of crashing out without a deal on March . “After months of refusing to take the chaos of no deal off the table, the Prime Minister must now face the reality that no deal is not an option. “I will meet the Prime Minister and others from across Parliament to find a sensible Brexit solution that works for the whole country. “That solution should be based around Labour’s alternative plan of a customs union with a UK say, a strong single market relationship and a cast-iron guarantee on workers’ rights, consumer standards and environmental protections.” The dramatic Commons showdown brings back Mrs May’s deal from the grave - but it looked likely to be temporary. She told MPs backing the Brady plan would help her send an “emphatic message” to the EU that they had to compromise to get a Brexit deal through Parliament. “What I’m talking about is not a further exchange of letters but a signicant and legally binding change to the withdrawal agreement,” she said. Downing Street said the PM was proposing three potential changes to the Brexit deal. The “alternative proposals” including technical solutions, a time limit on the backstop or a unilateral exit cause. The hardline ERG group of Brexiteer MPs backed the Brady plan at the last minute after the PM gave a nod to further discussions on the “Malthouse compromise”. This could eventually see the UK leaving the EU with a ‘managed’ no deal - which critics warned would lead to a serious dilution of workers rights. In the Commons, Mrs May said the group had put forward “a serious proposal that we are engaging with sincerely and positively”. She added: “We will sit down and work through the proposal that has come forward.” But she still faces the threat of a rebellion from Remainer ministers to avoid no deal. Justice Secretary David Gauke was said to have warned cabinet colleagues that hardline Brexiteers would always demand more. He joked they would eventually ask: “Why can’t you persuade France to give back Calais ” Ministers including Welfare Secretary Amber Rudd, business minister Richard Harrington and defence minister Tobias Ellwood remained on No s watchlist. However, the PM’s promise of another vote by February  staved off the rebellion for now. One cabinet source told the Mirror: “They were reassured that Parliament would be able to step innecessary,there was no deal, to keep us from accidentally falling off a clf.” It means that MPs will now have to wait two weeks for their next chance to vote on Mrs May’s plan - kicking the can yet further down the road. But there was confusion in the Tory ranks as to what the Brady amendment would achieve. One former cabinet minister told the Mirror: “Dferent groups are interpreting it in dferent ways.   “Some see it as the route to a World Trade Organisation exit. Others just a few tweaks to her deal. It’s a stitch up for tonight but means nothing.” Yet before MPs had even voted Mrs May was preparing her MPs for disappointment. It comes just weeks after she warned that reopening talks was impossible and that any changes had to lead to “negotiable” outcomes. Mr Tusk said the Northern Ireland backstop was not up for negotiation, but welcomed Parliament’s desire to avoid a no deal scenario. “We continue to urge the UK government to clary its intentions with respect to its next steps as soon as possible,” he said. “The Withdrawal Agreement is and remains the best and only way to ensure an orderly withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union. “The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for renegotiation.” Speaking in Cyprus moments before MPs voted, French president Emmanuel Macron added: “It is not renegotiable.”

title: brexit vote summary 7 key
story: NewsBrexit vote summary:  key moments on amendments night and what they meanTheresa May is now stronger and ready to fight the EU - but the battles impossible and it could all still turn against her. Weve learned a lot tonight - heres the Commons drama decodedShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video brexit-votes--seconds-amendments-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May has emerged stronger and ready to fight the EU after surviving a dramatic Brexit showdown. The Prime Minister defied fears shed lose a string of votes in the House of Commons on what she should do next. Instead, MPs backed her bid to re-open talks with the EU on the -page Brexit deal - including the Irish backstop. It means shes been thrown into a bitter battle with Brussels - whose chiefs say reopening talks is impossible. Tonights results mean Brexiteers have won the day, with MPs blocking a bid to delay the  March date of Brexit. But are more dramas to come, because despite everything, MPs did also agree to reject the prospect of a No Deal Brexit . And with just  days left until we leave the EU, talks are still deadlocked. The deadlocks just moved back from London to Brussels. Its all bafflingly complicated, we know. So here is a simple summary of the  key moments from tonight, and what they mean.  MPs have finally agreed on something about Brexit. Two weeks after Theresa Mays deal suffered an all-time record defeat, they rallied round a form that can work. And crucially, she was backed by  of the  Tory rebels who defeated her last time. That suggests thatshe gets what she wants - a BIG- she could WIN a final meaningful vote in two weeks time. MPs backed a fantasy bid to rewrite the -page Brexit deal, laid down by senior Tory Sir Graham Brady, by  votes to . As recently as last night, top Tory Brexiteers like Jacob Rees-Mogg were refusing to back the Brady amendment. But Mrs May won them round by promising legal changes to the Irish backstop, to stop it trapping the UK under EU customs rules. She pledged to rewrite a key clause by to look at alternative proposals, a time limit and a unilateral exit clause.   EU chiefs slammed the vote minutes after it happened - saying they WONT reopen talks on the -page Brexit deal. Instead theyre only offering to talk about the much smaller political declaration, which doesnt include the backstop. That leaves talks just as deadlocked as before. The deadlocks just moved from London to Brussels. An EU spokesman said: The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement. And the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation. If Brussels doesnt blink, MPs could turn back against Theresa May in a further vote on a revised deal around February . She told MPs: There is limited appetite for such a change in the EU and negotiating it will not be easy. But in contrast to a fortnight ago this House has made it clear what it needs to approve a withdrawal agreement.”  In a major but only symbolic move, MPs ordered Theresa May to reject a no deal Brexit. The amendment, which was proposed by Tory MP Caroline Spelman and Labours Jack Dromey, passed by just eight votes. While  voted to back the amendment,  voted against. It doesnt require the government to do anything legally but it shows clearly the feeling of the Commons. And it lays down a marker for what happens nextTheresa May DOESNT have any success with the EU. When she comes back to MPs on February , that feeling against a No Deal Brexit could turn into action.  MPs voted DOWN a bid to delay Brexit in a move that ramps up the odds of No Deal. The House of Commons rejected an amendment by Labour MP Yvette Cooper,  votes to , to extend the  March date of leaving the EUthere was no progress by February . The shock -vote majority was a crushing disappointment for Remainers who widely expected to block a damaging No Deal. And its a bizarre contradiction to MPs decisionthat they dont want a No Deal Brexit. Basically, MPs agree there should not be a No Deal Brexit. But they cant decide on how to block it.  The pound fell after MPs defeated a bid to delay Brexit. Sterling fell .% to the days low of .. It shows markets are still jittery about the prospect of a No Deal Brexit, which with  days to go, remains very, very real.  Jeremy Corbyn has agreed to meet Theresa May to try and break the Brexit deadlock. The Labour leader repeatedly refused to meet the Prime Minister until she ruled out no deal Brexit . But after Parliament voted to reject no deal, Mr Corbyn said he would meet with the PM - even though the vote was only symbolic. “I will meet the prime minister and others from across Parliament to find a sensible Brexit solution that works for the whole country, he said. “That solution should be based around Labour’s alternative plan of a customs union with a U.K. say, a strong single market relationship and a cast iron guarantee on workers’ rights, consumer standards and environmental protections.”  Theresa May had been expected to suffer a defeat at the hands of Tory rebels. But she was left much more secure, partly because she was backed by Labour ones. For example,  Labour MPs backed the Brady amendment. If theyve voted against, it would have still passed but by just a whisker. Meanwhile  Tory Remainers including Anna Soubry and Kenneth Clarke backed the plan by Yvette Cooper to delay Brexit. But  Labour MPs balanced them out by opposing Coopers plan - the majority of whom represent Leave-voting consituencies including Caroline Flint and Laura Smith as well as long term Brexiteers Ronnie Campbell and Kate Hoey. A further  Labour MPs abstained including Ruth Smeeth, Melanie Onn and Gloria De Piero who represent Leave-voting seats. And finally... We still dont know what the hell is going to happen  The message from tonight is weve had a string of contradictory messages - and no certain future for Brexit. Theresa May could still delay the date of Brexit in future, or be forced to, because MPs have made clear they dont want No Deal. Itll all turn against her, at least initially, when she has talks in Brussels. And it could all turn against her in Parliament tooshe doesnt get what she wanted. The next vote is on around February . Valentines Day. Will the PM get the love she craves - or will Britain be plunged into a brutal break-up

story: NewsChildren as young as  in county lines drug networks selling heroin and crackCity gangsters branching out into rural areas to sell heroin and crack-cocaine are using youngsters as couriersShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsTeenagers between  and  are believed to make up the bulk of the vulnerable people involved in county lines"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailUP to , children as young as  are being exploited by “county lines” drug networks, the National Crime Agency has warned. Criminal gangs are targeting youngsters to run the schemes, worth nearly poundmillion a year, a shock report warned County lines typically involves city gangsters branching out into smaller towns or rural areas to sell heroin and crack cocaine – often using youngsters as couriers because they are less likely to arouse suspicion. The phenomenon is so-called because of the phone lines used by dealers. Revealing the scale of the problem, the National Crime Agency’s investigations director Nikki Holland said: “Estimations from the report of , lines suggests that up to , children could be involved.” She told MPs that in  just seven police forces reported “being impacted on” by county lines.   But within two years all forces were affected, she said. Analysis by the NCA - dubbed “Britain’s FBI” - suggests there are more than , inidual deal line numbers in the UK - up from  in the last assessment. Highlighting the temptation to youngsters despite the dangers, National Police Chiefs Council serious violence coordinator, Assistant Chief Constable Jacqui Sebire, told the Commons Home Affairs Committee: “The county lines business model in some areas is actually the only option that they have to gain wealth, to gain prestige.” Warning of “cuckooing”, where gangs take over bank accounts and houses for drug dealing, Ms Sebire said the country was suffering a “real peak” in serious violence. “We have seen victims suffer the most horrendous injuries and they will still not either report or cooperate with the criminal justice approach,” she said. “They are much more scared of the county lines than they are of us.”   Analysis by the NCA found an inidual line can yield annual profits in excess of pound,. Some are estimated to generate thousands of pounds from a single daily delivery trip. They deploy children and vulnerable people as couriers to move drugs and cash between the new market and their urban hub. In its fourth annual assessment on the activity, the NCA said the supply of class A drugs through county lines is a “signicant, national threat”. Deputy Assistant Commissioner Duncan Ball, the NPCC’s gangs spokesman, said: “Wherever there is a drugs market, then the gangs will look to exploit it because we know each line brings in up to pound, a day. “Over the course of a year for one particular line we are looking at a signicant criminal enterprise.” Officers highlighted how offenders establish contact and build relationships with subjects before exploitation takes place. The analysis said: “This means that children may have been approached before the age of  in some cases as offenders seek to build a relationship that they can later exploit.” Gangs often target youngsters who are from poor backgrounds, have been kicked out of school or were previously in trouble with police. But children from “seemingly stable” backgrounds or without a criminal past are also targeted, according to the assessment. Offenders carry out recruitment both face-to-face and via social media, offering payments and material possessions victims would be unable to obtain through legal means. “This is enhanced by offenders’ use of social media, on which images and videos of cash, designer clothing, luxury cars and other high value goods are posted, creating a misconception that involvement in crime is rewarding,” the report said. It also flagged up an “emerging trend” around the use of app-based taxi services to transport offenders and potential exploitation victims to supply areas.   The area covered by the politan Police has the highest percentage of inidual deal lines, with %, followed by the West Midlands Policeand Merseyside Policeforce areas. The agency’s report said the county lines business model thrives on the exploitation of vulnerable adults and children to move and deliver drugs. Data from  indicates an age range of  to  for potential victims. Teenagers between  and  are believed to make up the bulk of the vulnerable people involved in county lines. Simon Blackburn, of the Local Government Association, said: “The exploitation of children and vulnerable adults by county lines drugs gangs is a signicant and growing concern for councils, who take this issue extremely seriously. “Effective partnership working at a local level between councils, the police, health services and charities and community organisations is essential to tackle and prevent drug related crime and safeguard those exploited by criminal gangs. “To help stop young people being exploited as drug runners, it is vital that government reverses years of funding cuts to local youth services, youth offending teams and councils’ public health budgets.”

title: fiona onasanya carry mp
story: NewsCan Fiona Onasanya carry on as an MP Fiona Onasanya was found guilty of perverting the court of justice in December after lying to police to avoid a speeding ticketShareByElaine McCahillAssistant News Editor:,  JAN NewsFiona Onasanya was jailed for three months after being found guilty of perverting the course of justice "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDisgraced MP Fiona Onasanya has been urged to do the decent thing and resign after she was jailed for lying to police over a speeding offence. She was sentenced to three months in prison, and will serve half her sentence, after being found guilty of perverting the course of justice. Onasanya is the first woman MP to be sent to prison. The Peterborough MP was expelled by the Labour Party and has been working as an Independent since being found guilty last December. She is appealing her conviction butit upheld, a bi-election could be heldenough of her constituents sign a recall petition.  What is a recall petition  Under a law passed in , any MP suspended for more than  sitting days automatically triggers a recall petition that their constituents can sign. A recall petition can force a by-electionit is signed by more than % of the electorate in the Cambridgeshire seat. The petition will be open to sign for six weeks.Onasanya can then stand as a candidate in the by-election.As Onasanya is appealing her conviction and no recall petition can happened until this is dealt with. A recall petition can be openedan MP has been: convicted of an offence and received a custodial sentenceor ordered to be detained, other than solely under mental health legislation barred from the House of Commons for  sitting days or  calendar days, or convicted of providing  or misleading information for allowance claims under the Parliamentary Standards Act . What did Fiona Onasanya do  The Peterborough MP, who was expelled by the Labour Party, was found guilty of perverting the course of justice by claiming someone  was driving her car on July  . The Old Bailey heard how Miss Onasanyas Nissan Micra was clocked speeding at mph in a mph zone after visiting a former political aide in her constituency. When she was sent a Notice of Intended Prosecution, Mr Onasanya, , sent it back claiming a Russian man was driving, even though he was abroad. At the time, Miss Onasanyas le as a new MP was chaotic and she was coming to terms with being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. But when she was pursued by police, she maintained her brothers lie out of misguided loyalty with disastrous consequences, the court heard. Mr Justice Stuart-Smith said he was certain she had been behind the wheel on July  and had she accepted the speeding offence it would have had no real or lasting embarrassment to her as an MP. He told her: The impact of your conviction has been disastrous for you. The court heard Mr Onasanya, from Cambridge, provided  details to avoid speeding prosecutions on two other occasions. He had nine points on his licence and faced losing his licencehe got any more, the court heard. He was sentenced to  months in prison. Who is urging her to resign  Following her sentencing both Labour and Conservatives urged her to do the decent thing and step down. A Labour Party spokesman said she had let the voters of Peterborough down and should have resigned when she was convicted in December. He said: However, todays sentence gives Fiona one last opportunity to act honourably and resign from Parliament. She should do this without delay and not take another penny in salary from the public purse. If Fiona does not resign, Labour will support local residents in their efforts to trigger a by-election through a recall petition. A Conservative Party spokesman said: She cannot possibly represent her constituents from prison and should do the decent thing and immediately step down. If she doesnt, we will campaign to use a recall petition to ensure that the residents of Peterborough can have their say in a by-election for a new MP. Labour are ignoring the democratic vote of Peterborough and are doing all they can to frustrate Brexit for political purposes. The people of Peterborough deserve a Conservative MP who will respect their views. Miss Onasanya took the marginal seat from the Tories with a majority of just  at the  election just  months ago. Parliamentary rules require the removal of an MP who is jailed for  months or more. But with a lesser sentence, a recall petition can force a by-electionit is signed by more than % of the electorate in the Cambridgeshire seat.

Ivan Dagg, ,was told he had just a % chance of successful chemotherapy treatment after being diagnosed with bowel and liver cancer in .But, after five years of multiple tumour removals and a wold-first liver operation, the father-of-two has been given the all clear, reports Hull Live .Ivan, an inspection engineer from Hull, first noticed something wasnt right with his health when he began losing weight and feeling constantly exhausted five years ago. After being diagnosed with stage four bowel cancer, Ivans health further deteriorated when the cancer spread to his liver - meaning he needed four procedures and chemo to save his le.  Last January, Ivan underwent his final surgery - with doctors saying without the procedure, he only had a few months to live. The operation at Spire Hospital in Leeds was hailed as a world-first after doctors found Ivan had grown a new vein in his liver, opening up a new and previously unknown avenue to recovery for others with a similar condition. Speaking about his emotional cancer journey, Ivan said: The last few years have been a rollercoaster. I’m finally feeling positive about my future. “I woke up after surgery and Professor Lodge told me he had been able to remove the tumour. That was fantastic to hear. “Now I’m back at work and looking forward to the future with my family. Nobody knows what’s going to happen in the future but I feel very lucky. There could have been a very dferent outcome.”   Ivans surgery was carried out by Professor Peter Lodge, who described the surgery as very high risk. Speaking about the complicated procedure, world-leading expert in liver surgeries Prof Lodge said: Things went well so we were able to remove the tumour successfully along with the major hepatic veins, leaving Ivan’s liver surviving on only the new vein. “If he had not grown a new vein then I would not have been able to do the surgery. This was very high-risk and extremely complicated liver surgery and one of the most dficult that I have ever had to do. “Without surgery, Ivan would have been faced with having only a few months to live. I think that chemotherapy may have given him a few extra months but that’s all. It’s still early days but I’m very pleased with Ivan’s progress.”

story: NewsMan free to take mothers le due to police officer blunderXeneral Webster, , doused Joanne Rand, , from head to with a corrosive substanceShareByTom Pettor:,  JAN NewsXeneral Webster "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA killer was free to take a mother’s le after a police officer allegedly failed to pass on information about a previous acid attack, it emerged yesterday. Xeneral Webster, , doused Joanne Rand, , from head to with a corrosive substance. The mum-of-three, who worked as a carer, died in June  of multi-organ failure after contracting septicaemia due to acid burns. The police watchdog is investigating after it emerged that a Met Police officer had been investigating another acid attack on a woman, allegedly by Webster, three months earlier.  The officer obtained CCTV footage of the incident in North London in March , but allegedly did not circulate it for  months, until November . Police identied the suspect as Webster, who was already in prison for  years for Ms Rand’s manslaughter. The Independent Office for Police Conduct is now investigating the officer involved in a gross misconduct case, for alleged breaches of professional standards. The IOPC’s Jonathan Green, said: “This investigation raises the very serious question about the way a Met Police officer may have handled a crucial piece of evidence which may have identied the suspect of an acid attack.”  Ms Rand was attacked while sitting on a bench in High Wycombe, Bucks. A court heard Webster travelled to the area with sulphuric acid, which was knocked from his grasp by another man during a scuffle over a bicycle, covering Ms Rand in the substance. Webster, of Westway, West London, admitted manslaughter at his murder trial at Reading crown court. Ms Rand’s daughter, Katie Pitwell, , said afterwards: “With gang and drug crimes becoming so widespread, it is proven now that people do die from acid attacks. “This will never bring my mum back. I have to live with the fact that she’ll never be at my wedding or see my progress through le.”

title: men who acted like pack
story: NewsMen who acted like pack of wild animals in sickening attack jailedKia Morrison, , was left with devastating injuries after he was punched and kicked in the head by Callum Musgrove and Dylan West, both , outside a nightclub in Teesside last MayShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  JAN NewsMusgrove was jailed for -and-a-half years at Teesside Crown Court "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo thugs who acted like a pack of wile animals as they carried out a sickening attack outside a nightclub have been jailed. Callum Musgrove and Dylan West, both , were sentenced to  years for the devastating assault on aspiring soldier Kia Morrison on May  last year. Mr Morrison, just  at the time, suffered le-changing injuries when he was punched by West and horrendously kicked in the head by Musgrove. His injures stopped stopped him pursuing his dreams of joining the army and ever having children. The fracas began when their friend Aaron Thompson was thrown out of the Soho nightclub in central Middlesbrough in the early hours of Bank Holiday Monday. Thompson hurled abuse at doormen, saying they had made a big mistake and they did not know who they were dealing with, and threatening to come back with a shotgun and shoot them. The other two joined him and the three -year-olds launched indiscriminate violence against door staff and other people, apparently sparked by the loss of a gold chain.   Within a minute or so, there was a brawl with Musgrove at its heart, prosecutor Nick Dry told Teesside Crown Court on Tuesday. He said Musgrove - who had received boxing training and fought two bouts - was dancing around asboxing on Albert Road. Mr Morrison walked by with his uncle as he saw the violence and tried to usher Musgrove away, the Crown said. He threw a missed punch as he backed away from an advancing Musgrove, who struck him with force. Then he was hit by West. Finally Musgrove kicked the dazed victim to the head and he fell to the pavement unconscious. The teenager suffered a complex skull fracture and a bleed on the brain and was fitting and bleeding heavily as he was taken to hospital with le-threatening injuries. He survived but faced the prospect of signicant disability for the rest of his le, using a wheelchair and needing help in day-to-day le. The attack destroyed his hopes of joining the Army and affected his speech, communication and his ability to enjoy becoming a father.   His grandmother stepped into the witness box to give a harrowing statement about the far-reaching effects on him and his family. Musgrove, appearing with West via video link to Durham Prison, cried as she spoke movingly in the courtroom. Yobs shouted that victim deserved it and they hoped he would die Yet at the time, Musgrove and West celebrated their assault, the former re-enacting his kick, the court was told. Some of the group were heard to shout that Mr Morrison had deserved it and they hoped he would die, added Mr Dry. Yobs removed shirts and carried on fighting with doormen, who took two men to the ground before the police arrived and arrested them. Others were injured in the melee - a doorman suffering a cut eye, another with bite marks to his arm, and a man kicked on the ground. West showed no remorse after his arrest, asking police: What am I being locked up for  Attempted murder  Thats the best thing for him. He and Musgrove claimed they acted in self-defence or as a peacemaker.   Musgrove, of Monksfield, Billingham, and West, of Norton Road, Norton, both admitted inflicting grievous bodily harm. But Musgrove was convicted by a jury of the more serious charge of causing grievous bodily harm with intent. They and Thompson, of The Heath, Norton, admitted affray. In his trial Musgrove apologised to Mr Morrison from the witness box, saying: Im sorry mate, and I hope you recover. I was acting like an absolute d***head and Im ashamed of myself. He had only a reprimand for theft on his record, Thompson a warning for assault as a youth and a fine for two assaults on police officers. West had been cautioned for racially abusing and punching a shopkeeper unconscious. He was given a suspended prison sentence for two assaults on Christmas Eve  , where he pulled a kne and threw punches at door staff when he was refused entry to a casino. Brian Russell, defending Musgrove, said: He still doesnt really understand why he behaved in that way. The reason he behaved in that way was because he had had too much to drink. He said Musgrove panicked over the loss of his gold chain and was described by a neighbour as a caring and gentle young man who had done work for charity.   Robert Mochrie, representing West, said he did not play the leading role, saying he got between the two to avoid any further confrontation and did not foresee the consequences when he delivered a single punch. Alex Bousfield, for Thompson, said he was not involved in the attack on Mr Morrison and struck out in panic when a group of males came towards him amid arguments with door staff. He said Thompson later apologised, regretted his foolish drunken behaviour and stayed out of trouble since. Judge Simon Bourne-Arton QC, the Recorder of Middlesbrough, rejected the suggestion that Mr Morrison had squared up before the attack. He said: I do not accept for one moment that hes to be blamed in any part whatsoever. He said Thompson was the catalyst for the chain of events and Musgrove was jumping up and down, squaring up to them and your adrenaline was pumping. Why you were behaving that way I have no idea. He said Musgroves dreadful kick had catastrophic effects and consequences and le-changing injuries which, it was thought for many months, might prove fatal. He told Musgrove and West: After the attack you two went off relishing and celebrating about what you had done. Those who go for a night out are entitled to enjoy a decent night out without being confronted by people like you. Musgrove was jailed for -and-a-half years, West for five years, and Thompson for  months.

title: miracle birth overjoyed mum who
story: NewsMiracle birth for overjoyed mum who had heart, lung and liver transplantEXCLUSIVE Lucinda Simpson, , became the first woman to give birth after having a triple heart, lung and liver transplantShareCommentsByRachel Williams:,  JAN NewsLucinda, Damon and Angus "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLiving heart donor Lucinda Simpson is believed to be the only woman to have received, given and created the gt of le.Having been told she would never have a baby, the -year-old became the first woman to give birth after having a triple heart, lung and liver transplant.It is not the only record under her belt. In , Lucinda also became one of just four successful living heart donors. All of them had “domino” transplants, where their hearts were gted to others while they were receiving donor organs. Doctors believe Lucinda, mum to nine-month-old Angus, is a one-off. She says: “When Angus was born last April, he became the only baby in the world to be born to a woman after a heart, lung and liver transplant.”   Yet Lucinda is well aware of the thousands who are not so fortunate. She hopes the Mirror’s Change the Law for Le campaign for an opt-out organ donor system inspires the rest of the world. “Without my donor, none of this would have been possible, which is why I’m backing the Mirror campaign to introduce the opt-out system,” she says. “Sadly, so many lives are lost due to long waiting times for transplant surgery in the UK.” Lucinda, from Queensland, Australia, was born with cystic fibrosis, which damages the lungs and digestive system, and always knew she would one day need a lung transplant. “If you think of lungs as the size of a two-litre milk container, I was breathing ml instead of ,ml,” she says. “I had to stop shyworking, which I hated as my brain was fine. It was just that I couldn’t keep up. I couldn’t vacuum, make the bed or even do the dishes.”   Lucinda’s condition got so bad due to all her heavy medication that, by her early s, her liver had deteriorated. Doctors opted to replace her heart as well as her lungs and liver. She says: “My heart worked perfectly fine, but the doctors explained it would be easier to replace all three organs in one go. “It was easier to do the surgery like a car engine: put the heart, lungs and liver in as a block. You just lt one lot out and put the other lot in, so there are fewer connections.” Before the surgery Lucinda started dating her future husband, Damon. She says: “Other blokes I’d dated were like, ‘She’s just too high maintenance, I don’t want to deal with that’. “We’d only been seeing each other for a few weeks when I told him all about my condition and what was in store. “But he said, ‘Evenyou had no arms or legs and you were just a head, I’d buy you awesome hats for Christmas’. I knew then he was a keeper.   “I hadn’t even made it to the operating table yet, but I’d already given my heart away, to Damon.” Ten months later, on her th birthday, Damon proposed. The pair asked Lucinda’s pre-transplant teamshe would ever be able to carry a baby. She says: “We were told it was unlikely I’d survive long enough to have a family.” Then in June , four months before their wedding, the couple got a call as they were having dinner. Lucinda says: “I was told I was gettshying my transplant that night. Damon told me he loved me, then I was wheeled into the operating room while he waited with my parents, Kaylene and Jim.” A recipient was found for Lucinda’s healthy heart. “It was incredible, but it was bittersweet. “To give me a chance, someone had lost their le,” she says. Having been in and out of hospital all her le, Lucinda was not fazed as she waited to be put to sleep. “I was looking around fascinated at all the surgical instruments asking, ‘What does that do ’ “They’re like, ‘That’s going to separate your rib cage. This machine will be your heart and lungs for you as we operate’. I thought that was so cool. “I even asked to keep my old organs in a jar, but they suggested I donate them to medical science, which sounded like a much better idea.”   The -hour operation was a success and Lucinda was able to go ahead with her wedding, exactly two years to the day she first met Damon. Five years later, she told her doctor of her hopes of getting pregnant. “By then, he thought carrying a baby wouldn’t be a risk to my le. But it wasn’t as easy as just trying to fall pregnant,” Lucinda says. Her daily cocktail of medicine had to be carefully assessed to make sure it would not cause birth defects or miscarriage. Then, Lucinda’s heart, lung and liverhad to be rigorously tested. Getting ready to have a baby took years. “Pregnancy was not something we were rushing into,” she says. “We were not being irresponsible.” As the years passed, and she failed to conceive, Lucinda began to lose hope. Then, after their th wedding anniversary in , a routine blood test revealed she was pregnant. “We were both so surprised, Damon and I burst into happy tears,” Lucinda says. “The day before the -week scan, on Valentine’s Day, I felt our baby kick for the first time.” Angus was delivered  weeks early by emergency caesarean on April  last year,  years after the transplant.   “We’d been warned that, being a transplant mum, I was unlikely to go to full term. But giving birth at six months was way earlier than we expected,” Lucinda says. At just lb oz, Angus was whisked to the neonatal intensive care unit. Lucinda says: “I wasn’t allowed to see Angus for  hours. Even after that, I could only place my hands on him. “I just cried. I was so happy to have him, but I didn’t want him to be in a little glass box. I finally got to cuddle him when he was  days old.” The couple were allowed to take Angus home after nearly three months, when he had reached .lbs. He is happy and healthy. Lucinda adds: “I tease Damon, saying, ‘Do you want to do it again ’ He just replies, ‘I think we’ve been blessed with one’.”

story: NewsMum becomes best friends with other woman who had love rat boyfriends secret babyCarol Avenell, , from Bromley, London, was heartbroken to learn John* had been having an affair with -year-old Shelley Broughton - but now they are like familyShareCommentsByJulia Sidwell:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsCarol [right] admitted at the beginning of their relationship, sex with John [left] was electric "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who was devastated to discover her love rat boyfriend had fathered a child with a secret girlfriend has revealed how she became best friends with the other woman. Carol Avenell, , from Bromley, London, was heartbroken to learn John* had been having an affair with -year-old Shelley Broughton. After coming clean, he promised his infidelity was simply a drunken one-night stand and Carol agreed to give the relationship another go. But when the two women started talking for the sake of their children,Charlotte, now , and Lydia, nine, they realised he was seeing them both at the same time. After both ditching John, the former rivals are now the best of friends - and even feel grateful that Johns actions brought them together. Were family, said Carol, speaking of their ten year friendship. I’m so glad we found each other. Carol told how initially she was attracted to how handsome John was – admitting their sex le was electric.   John had me smitten, she said. He was handsome and charming to boot. The more I saw of him the more I liked him. And I was thrilled when I realised he liked me too. We became a couple and spent our time down the pub having a laugh with friends. Sure enough, I was quickly falling head over heels for him. But it wasn’t all smooth sailing. We had our ups and downs and sometimes when we went out, John would end up flirting with other women. I couldnt blame them - he was gorgeous after all. And though there were times when I was fed up, there was something about John that always reeled me back in. He was like my drug I was addicted to him. Plus, our sex le was electric. Five years later, John sat Carol down and told her he wanted a baby.   My mouth gaped open in shock, Carol said. The topic of children had never come up before. But deep down, my stomach fluttered. I was excited to be starting a family with the man I loved. Three months later, I was staring at a positive pregnancy test. But when I broke the news to John, he looked stunned. He nodded slowly, as though reality had just smacked him round the face. He became distant and I had no idea what had come over him. Maybe he’s just scared, I thought. Months later I went into labour and I phoned John to tell him. At hospital, as my contractions grew closer, I waited for him to burst through the doors. Instead, I found myself giving birth to our daughter, Charlotte, without him. As soon as I cradled her in my arms, my worries disappeared. Until two hours later, when John finally turned up. At first, he was the proudest dad. He went from pub to pub, showing Charlotte off to all his mates. But it wasn’t long before he seemed to get bored. He spent less time with us and more time at work or out drinking. Even though I was still in love with John, our time apart grew and grew until I barely even saw him anymore. And then day, when Charlotte was almost three, I was surprised to receive a call from him out of the blue.   John revealed he had another daughter called Lydia and he wanted them to visit her. He said Lydias mum was a drunken one-night stand and they were no longer together. Carol said: After I’d hung up, my mind whirled. I couldn’t believe that my John, The One, had another family. Days later, I took Charlotte to the pub we’d agreed to meet at. I knew Lydia’s mum was coming along, so I downed a bottle of WKD for courage. And when I saw her, I was glad I had. She looked like she meant business. I smiled at her baby lying innocently in the buggy. My blood was boiling at the whole situation but it wasn’t the child’s fault. John appeared and we all chatted, before Shelley and I went into the beer garden, leaving the girls inside with him. Shelley asked what hed said about her and I told her, he said it was a one-night stand. Shelley burst out laughing - theyd been together for  months. My stomach flipped.  Shelley told Carol while they had been in a serious relationship, they had since split up. Later, fuelled with rage, Carol confronted John. Carol said: He told me she was lying and nothing happened between them. I thought maybe she was trying to make me jealous, so I ed home with Charlotte and soon, John seemed to start taking an interest in me again. I was thrilled when we picked up where we left off. The five of us continued to meet up regularly for the girls’ sake and It was lovely to see them bond. On Lydia’s first birthday we got together again, but John couldn’t make it. It was awkward without him there. There was a tension between me and Shelley and we had no choice but to talk. The more we chatted, the more John’s lies unraveled. He had told Shelley he had given me loads of money - despite never giving me a penny. But as soon as I spoke to him, he shook it all off. He assured me he was a liar and told me not to believe a word she said. I decided Shelley fancied John and was trying to put me off him. But we continued our meet-ups and the more time I spent with Shelley, the more it dawned on me. She wasn’t the liar, John was.  Carol decided to put her cards on the table and tell Shelley they were an item. But when she did, Shelley had her own version of events. Carol said: She said John had been pulling her into the bedroom at every opportunity. So hed been lying to us both - having his cake and eating it too. She explained they had split when she was pregnant and nothing had been going on at the time of our first visit. But soon after, things had started up between them again – around the same time Tony had been wooing me. Suddenly it all made sense. He’d been playing us off against each other, badmouthing us to one another so we wouldn’t become friends. From that moment on, Shelley and I became firm pals. We still met up with John so the girls could be with their dad, until he stopped making the effort. But all was not lost. The four of us had each other. Shelley and I see each other as much as we can and spend birthdays and Christmas together. We love nothing more than to watch our girls dress up in Disney outfits, dancing around the room together giggling. Charlotte and Lydia have each other as sisters and that is something really special. They are as thick as thieves – just like me and Shelley. We’re family. Thankfully we were able to see through John’s lies and have put everything that happened behind us. Despite the deceit and heartbreak, I’m so glad we found each other. And now we know that everything happens for a reason.  Shelley Broughton, , said: Carol and I were so in love with John that for a while we couldn’t see he was lying to us both. I had my suspicions and but John was always managed to convince me otherwise. I’m just so glad we have come out the other side and have each other as friends. I really want others who have gone through a similar situation to read our story and realise that it doesn’t have to end badly. You never know, you might even come out a happier person. *John is not his real name

story: NewsMum reveals horror moment doctors said her babys body was shutting downSam Marwood, , from Burton Pidsea, Yorkshire, said that she didnt know that babies could take Dioralyte which could have helped her sons conditionShareCommentsByTom Kershaw:,  JAN NewsMum Sam, , with son Vincent "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother has opened up about how doctors told her her baby’s body was “shutting down” after he was rushed to hospital with a vomiting bug. Little Vincent Marwood, nine months, was so close to death his legs and arms we’re “fading away to a grey colour” and medicine had to be drilled into his shin bone in order for it to be administered as quickly and possible. Sam Marwood, , said that after her son caught the bug he was constantly sick for  hours and was unable to keep down even a drop of water or milk. She also became deeply concerned after noticing he was “red all over” when she changed his nappy so called the emergency services.Vincent lost consciousness while being rushed to Hull Royal Infirmary where doctors told her his body was shutting down, reports Hull Daily Mail . Sam, of Burton Pidsea, a village near Hull, Yorkshire, said: “It was very scary. I was laid on the stretcher with Vincent on top of me when we arrived at hospital and we were suddenly surrounded by four brilliant doctors. They asked me was it ok to do this and do that, and I said yes, anything, but the frowns on their faces told the story. The top doctor told the other doctors that they were wasting time and he was too ill and that his legs and arms were fading away with a grey colour. I thought we were going to lose our beautul boy. Lucky after the medicine was given to him Vincent began to respond well to glucose, fluids and antibiotics.   His levels had dropped to a critical level and the mum-of-two was told seizures, organ failure and limb loss would have been possible without her quick thinking and “mothers instinct”. Sam, who works as a sales assistant at Topshop, was shocked when she was told she could have helped her sons state by giving him hydration replacement Dioralyte, which would have helped rehydrate Vincent after being constantly sick. She said: I didnt know anything about the hydration sachets for babies and how they could help young children, because too much salt in babies can be really harmful. Giving advice to other parents, following the familys scare on January , Sam, also a mother to Henry, two, said: As a mum I read anything and everything about baby health dangers, but still didn’t think this situation was as bad as it was - until it was.

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge were in Scotland to open a poundmillion museum - just miles away from where they first locked eyes on each other in  at the University of St Andrews.It is the first official joint engagement of the year for the pair, known as the Earl and Countess of Strathearn when in the country. Today she teamed the coat with black gloves, black block heels, a Manu Atelier green leather bag and pair of Princess Diana’s sapphire earrings.McQueen is a firm favourite of Kates, with Sarah Burton from the luxury fashion house designing the Duchesss wedding dress in .
