Scotland has a special place in their hearts as it is where their love story began in  while studying at the University of St Andrews .The attraction they opened this afternoon is the centrepiece of a poundbillion transformation of the Dundee waterfront, once part of the citys docklands. While meeting schoolchildren Kate remarked that she has “never seen a museum like this”. William , , and Kate , , the first royal patron of the VA, also met the team who helped create the poundmillion venue which has garnered interest from across the globe.It is named after Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, William’s great-great-great-great grandparents. More than , people have visited the museum since it opened to the public in September. It was designed by Japanese architect Kengo Kuma and the building takes its inspiration from the clfs along the north-east coast and stretches out into the River Tay. Kate and Wills were given a tour and shook hands with Mr Kumo before complimenting his work.   Kate also took to the stage and gave a speech in which she said: William and I are so pleased to be back here in Dundee to celebrate the opening of this wonderful museum today. Thank you so much for inviting us. Last February I was delighted to become patron of the VA in London. Now nearly a year later I am thrilled to be standing in a brand new VA - one which has been built for the city of Dundee and for Scotland. She added: “I hope that VA Dundee will serve as an inspiration to others by showing how great things can be achieved when dferent communities pull together and work for the common good. I have been captivated by the breathtaking architecture, and the sheer range of design on display. But most of all I’ve been moved by the passion of the people who work here, and the dedication of all those who have helped make this important project to succeed.   After leaving the multi-million pound building, Kate and Wills both wrapped up in scarves and headed outside to greet the well-wishers, some waving flags, who had gathered to see the VIP visitors. Kate, who was holding a gorgeous bouquet of flowers, stopped and chatted to the crowds, including to one woman who clutched the Duchesss hand. While William was seen speaking to adorable schoolchildren keen to show him their artwork of a Scottish flag. The royal pair were then driven to The Crescent community centre where they were greeted by the Lord Provost Ian Borthwick and a chorus of cheers from onlookers. They sat and had tea and cake with Dundee Michelin factory employees to hear first-hand how they have been affected by the news that tyre production is to cease on the site. It has been a huge part of the city and a key employer for generations. Last year it was announced it has been earmarked for closure, with around  people facing redundancy.  William later spoke at a meeting of the Michelin Dundee Action Group in which he said he hoped a positive way forward could be found during the period of uncertainty in the community. Todays visit also aimed to build on Kate’s keen interest in promoting the visual arts, and highlighting the value that public institutions like VA Dundee can offer local communities, particularly in terms of increased accessibility to world- class art and design. VA Dundee director Philip Long said: We are honoured to be welcoming the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge to officially open VA Dundee. This official opening marks the beginning of a very exciting year, with upcoming exhibitions on videogames, robots and the future of design.   Through an eclectic programme, we aim to inspire people and provoke discussion about the role of design in everyones lives. Meanwhile, Scotland is where Kate and William first locked eyes on each other. They were studying at the University of St Andrews, and quickly became close after realising they shared the same naughty sense of humour. William studied history of art before switching to geography, while Kate studied art history. They both achieved :. The prince graduated alongside Kate in June  when he was .

story: NewsSick man living on food parcels and facing bankruptcy due to Universal CreditJohn Betts, , says he owes thousands due to the roll-out of the much-criticised benefits system last yearShareCommentsByTony EarnshawNeil Murphy:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video universal-credit-left-man-thousands-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA sick man who racked up pound, in debts say he has been left on the verge of bankruptcy due to Universal Credit . John Betts suffers from a range of debilitating health issues and has been unable to work since suffering a heart attack in . He lives in a tiny, one-bedroom council home in Deighton, Huddersfield, ExaminerLive reports. The -year-old has now hit out at the much-criticised system which left people like him out of pocket. Vulnerable people need guidance on how benefits are paid, he says. John takes  dferent medications daily to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease , angina, arthritis and nerve tumours. He is also being treated for depression and has attempted to take his le on several dferent occasions.  Im on permanent sick now after working all my le. In my last job I was a chauffeur valet. I was told I had to move to Universal Credit otherwise my rent wouldnt get paid. Thats where the problems started. The information I got was that my rent was being paid and that the money I was getting in my account was mine,so I was spending that money. It was all jargon to me. Even when youre not stupid, its complicated. Butmy Universal Credit payments hadnt gone to pay the rent. Soon I was thousands of pounds in debt and the court was trying to summons me for my council tax as well. I had no idea I owed them that money.  He estimates that he owes pound, in rent arrears and is afraid that he will eventually lose his tenancy. The Citizens Advice Bureau is steering John towards bankruptcy to clear his debt in an attempt to live as normal a le as possible. But John says Universal Credit is to blame for his predicament over payments which are often delayed for weeks. He said: It takes eight weeks between transition of benefits. No one takes account of that. I got an advance but I didnt know that my rent had to come out of that. I offered to pay an extra pound a month on top of my pound rent to cover the debt but then I realised that I couldnt afford it. Once Ive paid everything out Im luckyI have pound left. The last time I got paid I had pound to my name.  John was given his tenancy last summer and moved into the unfurnished flat. At one stage he slept on a towel on a bare floor. He explains: Everything in the house has been given to me. Its all been donated except the TV, which I bought for pound. No one told me I was eligible to use the food bank at Huddersfield Mission. I had no idea that I could get help like that. They are fantastic people. I got a seven-day parcel with bread, packet rice, beans, tins of steak and tuna, milk, tea bags and butter. I also got fresh veg, frozen fish fingers and potatoes but without a cooker I cant cook them Im very grateful because it could be worse, but its not enough. How do I feel  I feel swept away, brushed to one side. Im not a priority.  The Citizens Advice Bureau said they would do a bank insolvency order so that they cant chase me anymore. The only way Im getting out of this is by going bankrupt. Id rather give them the moneyI had it because they deserve it, but I simply dont have it. What they are trying to do is for the best but the government is holding them back. I am determined to settle here and make a nice home. I want to be able to pay my bills and have nice things occasionally. I just need a chance. But Im being ignored and I want to be heard. The DWP have been contacted for comment.

story: NewsWoman, , tracked down birth mum for dream reunion over  years after adoptionPauline Jones, from Dublin, Ireland, was adopted from a Mother and Baby home in Ireland - and has finally met her -year-old biological mother, KathleenShareCommentsByKayla WalshAbigail OLeary:,  JAN News"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old woman tracked down her birth mother for a dream reunion -  years after she was adopted. Pauline Jones, from Dublin, Ireland, was adopted from a Mother and Baby home - but has now finally met her -year-old biological mother, Kathleen. As a tiny newborn, Pauline was carried away from her Kathleen and from the home in a shoebox and adopted. Two years, ago, having always wondered about her biological mum, Pauline decided to take a DNA test and track her family history. After years of searching and only coming across a handful of distant relatives, Pauline finally hit the jackpot after finding her birth mum Kathleen in November last year.Speaking to RSVP Live , Pauline said: I cant believe it. We look so alike, I got a fright when I first saw her.  “Even my gestures are the same as hers. I was just trying to take everything in. “Who would have thought a -year-old would find her mother. Kathleen, who lives in a nursing home in Dublin, sadly has early stages of dementia and for Paulines first few visits to her mum, there was no recognition or remembering who she was. Pauline said: My brother said ‘do you know who that is ’ and she said no. He said ‘Mam, do you remember years ago you had a baby and you had to give her up ’ “He called me Mary because that’s what my mother wanted me to be called - my adoptive mother called me Pauline Mary.   She kept looking at me but there was no sign of recognition. However, on Paulines third visit to her mum, she was amazed when a nurse, pointing at Pauline, asked Kathleenshe knew who she was, to which she replied: that’s my daughter. Pauline added that her mother is always happy to see her and asks her to come back to visit again. Because of her early dementia, Pauline still has unanswered questions about why she was adopted and who her father was. Pauline added: It’s a shame becauseI had looked for her sooner, I would have got answers from her. My brother said to me the other day - ‘I’m thrilled we found each other but we’ve wasted  years!’   “I said we’ll just have to make the most of the years we have.” Pauline, who has since found four siblings she never knew about, said she was against taking a DNA test for years as she didnt want to hurt the person raising her. She added: I was also afraid that I would find my mother and she would reject me. I couldn’t cope with that - I’d rather stay the way I was. “The reason I finally agreed to do it was because my son and grandson are big into family trees, and they were struggling because they didn’t know anything about mine.   “They also pointed out thatthere were any ailments in the family, they wouldn’t know about them. So I agreed to do it.” Pauline had suspected she was secretly related to her adoptive mother, who carried her out of a Mother and Baby Home on the North Circular Road in a shoebox. However so far the tests have found no connection.

title: Call for Inverness to get a share of cash for shop conversions
story: CONCERNS have been raised that Inverness could be denied a share of funding to help the hardest-pressed local high streets turn empty shops into housing.Mike Smith, manager of the cityrsquos Business Improvement Districtfears a move by the Federation of Small Businessesto persuade the Scottish Government to split a pound million fund between the poorest-performing high streets only could see a relatively buoyant Inverness miss out.ldquoI donrsquot think thatrsquos fair, he said.ldquoAll high streets are under certain pressures. Retail is a commercial venture and we do not think that public funds should be given tosupport one retail sector against another.ldquoI think this pound million should be fairly split on a population basis and should be used in an equal way to improve the infrastructure.Mr Smith stressed that some local authorities will already be investing in this way and their successes ldquoshould not be held against them.He said the redevelopment of Academy Streetrsquos former Farmfoods supermarket was ldquoa good example of shops being turned into homes in the city with the local authorityrsquos support.The development there will include  one-bedroom and  two-bedroom flats as well as four retail and office units on the ground floor.A spokesman for FSB nationally said: ldquoIt is far too early to tell which high streets will benefit from this fund.ldquoWersquore making the case for each local authority to use this money in the places that it could make the most dference.FSB Highlands and Islands development manager David Richardson said: ldquoRather than spreading the money too thinly for it to have any impact, the FSB wants it to be focused on ersying our hardest-pressed high streets and is calling for local authorities to establish new co-investment funds to improve and convert existing properties. We must make more of what wersquove already got. Allied to this is the need for joined-up thinking amongst public bodies. Given that thriving high streets and village centres are inextricably linked to the health and wellbeing of their communities, it is important that all interested parties work in partnership.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister said she would be calling on colleagues to get round the table for some strategic planning to make sure the city gets a share of the funding.She believes the rate of shop closures in the Highland capital and the long waiting list for homes puts the city at the front of the queue.She said: ldquoIrsquom going to have a chat with the city centre manager, David Hass, and get people around the table to see how we can get our hands on that money.Wednesday  Jan  : AM

title: Disused Daviot tourist site set for regeneration
story: A FORMER Culloden Academy pupil who has set up his own care business is to bring new le back to a former tourist office on the A just south of Inverness.Tim Cockinghopes to create up to  new jobs in the care sector and is looking for an operator to run a restaurant cafeacute type business from the former Visit Scotland office at Daviot.Formerly known as the Daviot Woods picnic site he is renaming it the lsquoNorth Gatewayrsquo.ldquoItrsquos right off the A and a perfect location for travellers passing through Inverness perhaps going to do the North Coast , said Mr Cocking who left Culloden when he was  with his family to live in Edinburgh.ldquoIrsquove seen the building when Irsquom visiting the north and itrsquos been looking rather sad and dilapidated and I thought there was something I could do with it.Mr Cockingrsquos Edinburgh-based company Brightcare has now applied to Highland Council for permission to change the use of the building to incorporate restaurant and retail facilities.ldquoThere once were public toilets there and itrsquos my intention to reinstate these once we have a thriving business on the site.His company Brightcare provides private home care for private clients looking for an alternative to residential care and already employs six people in the Highlands.ldquoWe have our HQ in Edinburgh and employ  people Scotland-wide and six of these jobs are in the Inverness area. But it is our intention to grow that business to about  jobs in the next few years.ldquoThe building at Daviot would also have an office for Brightcare. Itrsquos a well known building, bigger than we need for an office and there is space for both operations.ldquoI have already had expressions of interest from restaurant operators and a dog grooming business which would fit in well to because it is a popular area for people walking their dogs.Wednesday  Jan  : AM

title: Inverness Airport hotel plan takes off
story: The Courtyard by Marriot will be situated within Inverness Airport Business Park and it set to open its doors later this year.Owned and developed by Molo Hotels, the property will be operated by the independent hotel management company RBH.Chief business development officer at RBH, Andrew Robb, said the company is delighted to be working alongside Molo hotels and Polcom Construction for the project.ldquoWersquove forged a strong working relationship with Molo Hotels and Polocom Construction over the years and are thrilled to be working with them on what promises to be another outstanding property, said Mr Robb.The -bedroom hotel plans include meeting and fitness facilities as well as a bar and bistro.Contractor Polocom Construction has started the production of bedrooms in Poland before they are transported to the site near Inverness airport in May.A spokesman for RBH has said that the hotel is set to be open by the end of the year: ldquoWhile we canrsquot give an exact opening date at the moment, the hotel is scheduled to open in quarter  of  she said.Molo Hotels changed their name from Polocom Developments in .Wednesday  Jan  : AM

title: Inverness charity issues go orange plea for fundraising effort
story: INVERNESS charity Leorsquos Pride is encouraging people to lsquoGo orange for a dayrsquo as ambassadors in this yearrsquos Muscular Dystrophy UKevent on February .The national campaign has been running for three years and has so far made more than pound, by encouraging schools, workplaces and iniduals to wear orange for a day and make a donation to MDUK.Additionally those taking part can choose to wear sunglasses or even set up a mock-tail bar, in order to raise funds.Leorsquos Pride is a local organisation which was set up for Leo Flett, who is three-years-old and suffers from Muscular Dystrophy . Leorsquos mum Louise said: ldquoThe support we have had since starting almost a year ago is absolutely incredible and we continue to be touched by peoplersquos kindness and generosity.Mrs Flett said: ldquoWe are totally blown away by this yearrsquos response. We have been very lucky and honoured to have been asked to be ambassadors for the day this year by MDUK which means a lot to us considering wersquore still so new.The charity is raising money to continue their work finding new treatments and campaigning for better care and support for people with muscle-wasting conditions to ensure them the best possible quality of le.Muscular Dystrophy UK regional development manager, Dean Widd said: ldquoA huge thank you to everyone in Inverness looking to take part in the national Go Orange for a Day on February . We are delighted that over a dozen schools, clubs, academies and businesses have registered to take part in support of our Scottish family fund Leorsquos Pride.Mr Widd said: ldquoIt is thanks to the incredible efforts like this that we are able to continue to fund pioneering research into potential treatments for muscular dystrophy as well as supporting families. With more than , people in the UK living with muscular dystrophy and other muscle-wasting conditions, it is important to do whatever we can to make a dference.Leorsquos Pride is also organising an event in April called Pride  after last yearrsquos event which made over pound,.Wednesday  Jan  : AM

title: Leading Inverness football figure to live on with launch of fundraising campaign
story: THE memory of a leading Inverness football figure will live on with the launch of a fundraising campaign to help renal patients and raise awareness of kidney failure.Sandyrsquos Army will be launched in memory of Sandy Corcoran, the founder of Inverness City Ladies, on what would have been his th birthday.Mr Corcoran, who died three days before Christmas, had lived with type one diabetes for many years and then developed kidney failure resulting in him undergoing long dialysis sessions in Raigmore Hospitalrsquos renal unit.His family, including we, Valerie, son Steven and daughter Ashley Mackinnon, plus five grandchildren, are now raising funds for the unit at a dinner dance featuring live music and comedians at the cityrsquos Kingsmillrsquos Hotel on April .At the stroke of midnight, Sandyrsquos Army will be launched heralding more fundraising events in the coming year.Mrs Mackinnon said just  tickets remain for the event after  were snapped up in three days.ldquoWe want the night to be a massive celebration and we want to remember what an unbelievable person he was, she said. ldquoIt is going to be a sensational tribute to him as a person helping others and he would have wanted it no other way. It will be a hard day but I feel that being with those who loved him it will make it easier.Although Mr Corcoran was diagnosed with diabetes  years ago, he managed his condition but then developed kidney failure five years ago.With the support of his family, he started home dialysis but when it became too dficult he had to swap to six-hour sessions three days a week in the renal unit.ldquoThe unit became like a family to us, Mrs Mackinnon recalled. ldquoThey were just incredible to my dad. I noticed he was never on his own. They work tirelessly  hours a day, seven days a week.He was due to have a kidney and pancreas transplant but then developed bone marrow failure resulting in him having blood transfusions which meant he could not have a transplant.Sadly, Mr Corcoran, who was also the manager of Inverness Precast, died on December . Over  people attended his funeral.ldquoHe faced everything with the most unbelievable courage. I never once heard dad complain, Mrs Mackinnon said.She added that the family want to give something back to the renal unit and, as well as the dinner, planned fundraisers include an ascent of Ben Nevis.ldquoThis is a way of helping others through his memory.Wednesday  Jan  : AM

title: New bridge over the River Nairn is on track for summer
story: TEMPORARY weight restrictions on a busy rural road could be scrapped by the summer.Work to build a new crossing over the River Nairn to replace the ageing White Bridge is ldquoprogressing well and on track for completion by early summer, Highland Council has confirmed.The road bridge, which dates back to the th century and is category A listed, spans the river on the B route between Clephanton and Cawdor.It has been struggling to cope with heavy modern traffic and a weight limit of  tonnes has been in operation while a new bridge is built and the road realigned. The weight restriction has caused disruption for farmers, forestry vehicles and tour buses, which have been unable to use the existing bridge in the interim.The pound. million project is being handled by Dingwall-based RJ McLeod .Confirming that work is on track, Highland Council said that construction of the abutments for the new crossing beams was now complete and the beams were successfully hoisted into place this week.Now that the four beams are in place, contractor RJ McLeod will proceed with decking out between beams in preparation for concrete casting.Highland councillors in the Nairn and Cawdor ward, and Culloden and Ardersier wards ndash whose boundaries are spanned by the new crossing ndash have welcomed the progress being made.During the works the existing route has remained open to drivers, however all road users have been reminded about the -tonne weight restriction.Any vehicles which weigh more than this limit should use the ersion route, which goes via the A, A and B roads.Wednesday  Jan  : AM

title: New Lochardil hotel owner pledges to make investment
story: NEW owners of a well established Inverness hotel have promised more investment to make it even more attractive to visitors.Lochardil House Hotel has become the second mainland hotel bought by Skye-based Perle Hotels and the group has been advertising for staff to get ready for the summer.The Victorian mansion, which was built in  as the home of Inverness MP Charles Fraser-Mackintosh, has been a hotel since .It was previously owned by Eileen Fraser, who bought the hotel in . More recently she has expanded the hotel with the addition of a purpose-built banqueting suite, a conservatory restaurant, new kitchens and a separate  bedroom garden wing, more than doubling its accommodation provision.Perle Hotels marketing manager Nina Ghita said the group wanted to build on the hotelrsquos heritage and had no plans to change its name.ldquoWe want to keep those unique quirks and the history. Those are really important, but there are always things that can be improved, she said.ldquoWe focus on the Highlands and Islands and we invest quite heavily into the hotels, provide more jobs and just try and make something special within the area. The same thing will be happening with Lochardil. Obviously the hotel is in a really good position as it is. We donrsquot have any concrete plans as yet, but there will be heavy investment down the road.Unlike the grouprsquos previous hotels, which required major renovations, she does not anticipate anything so drastic. There are no immediate plans to add other north hotels to the group, but Ms Ghita pointed out there were opportunities available all the time.ldquoWe are a growing company, she said. ldquoThere will be future expansion plans but nothing concrete at the moment.Wednesday  Jan  : AM

title: Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds to play Inverness concert
story: They will perform at Bught Park on Saturday, June , as part of lsquoLive in the Cityrsquo, a series of summer music concerts planned for the city.Last year was a successful period for the former Oasis star, who landed a Mercury Prize nomination for the High Flying Birdsrsquo album Who Built The Moon , the bandrsquos third number one in a row. They also toured extensively across North America, Europe and Asia with Noel picking up the Best Album and Solo Artist accolades at the Q Awards.Joining the line-up for the evening, are two big names from the music scene. Indie rock band, Razorlight and Neon Waltz shy- from John OrsquoGroats - will be special guests on June .Local concert promoter, LCC Live is organising this concert, as part of its lsquoLive in the Cityrsquo. Carlie Davidson of LCC Live, said: ldquoNoel is a legend of the music industry, who along with his band, will take to the stage and deliver an array of classic songs from his career including recent hits Holy Mountain and Itrsquos A Beautul World.ldquoWersquore absolutely delighted to be organising his only Scottish outdoor show in  at our fantastic arena in Bught Park. It will be a great night and Noel Gallagherrsquos High Flying Birds, is a superb addition to our eclectic series of live concerts this summer.Tickets for Noel Gallagherrsquos High Flying Birds concert in Inverness go on sale at am on Friday from Ticketline www.ticketline    or in person from Cafferys Menswear, Eastgate Shopping Centre, Inverness, IV PP.Wednesday  Jan  : AM

title: Parents criticise new school bus service across Inverness
story: SCHOOL bus services have been in chaos since a council contract changed hands at the start of the month it has been claimed.Parents say a move to double up dedicated school runs with services for the general public since transport giant Stagecoach took over the Highland Council schools contract from DE Coaches on January  has seen pupils regularly forced to endure late-running and dangerously overcrowded buses.Police have also confirmed they are investigating allegations that pupils were threatened with a weapon on board a bus between Kirkhill and Charleston Academy on January .Mum Carol Paterson, whose daughter travels from Croy to Culloden Academy, said the problems are known about across Inverness.ldquoThe children at Croy are waiting sometimes up to  minutes in freezing conditions because the buses are now regularly late, she said.ldquoAnd when they board the bus there are not enough seats.Jools Lawson, whose daughter attends Charleston Academy, said: ldquoKids are regularly having to stand on a jam-packed bus or being put off altogether and told to wait for another one.ldquoThe service is disgusting and Stagecoach brush our complaints under the carpet.Posts from a private Facebook group set up for parents of pupils using school buses and shown to the Inverness Courier make clear the extent of unhappiness since the changeover.Other alleged incidents include children being put off a bus beside a busy main road without a pavement and two incidents involving Inverness Royal Academy pupils ndash one where a bus did not turn up at home time and another where the bus was too small to accommodate them.Highland Council has issued two separate statements in response to concerns raised ndash one with regard to a public service operating en route to Inverness Gaelic Primary stating it is unlikely to involve ldquoroutes which the public are likely to want to use and another on the Charleston Academy-Kirkhill route stating ldquomeasures have been put in place to make improvements.Despite this an online petition has been launched calling for the reinstatement of dedicated school services.Signed by almost  people so far it states: ldquoWhen putting our children on a school bus it used to be the case that it was only school children on these buses, therefore anyone travelling was accounted for and any incidents easily dealt with and tracked.ldquoNow we have opened the floodgates to allowing our children to be exposed to anything on these buses.Councillor for Culloden and Ardersier, Glynis Campbell-Sinclair, said Highland Council needs to launch its own investigation into whether there is a serious problem with how buses taking pupils to and from schools operate.ldquoThey cannot jam pack children onto buses like pilchards and hope there is not going to be an accident - especially in this weather, she said.ldquoEvery parent that sends their child to school by bus is depending on the council to ensure that happens safely.ldquoIt is the councilrsquos responsibility as corporate parent to ensure these children get to school safely.A spokeswoman for Stagecoach North Scotland said: ldquoSince we started operating the additional school contracts on January  there have been some issues with capacity we have identied and are working to resolve.ldquoWe are working closely with Highland Council to resolve these problems by issuing school children with passes allocating them to specic buses to prevent the overloading problems we have seen.She added that in terms of the issues raised by Mrs Paterson an additional bus is now running to and from Croy.Wednesday  Jan  : AM

title: Work starts on new outlets at Eastgate Shopping Centre
story: WORK has begun at the Eastgate Shopping Centre in Inverness to develop four food outlets.The units, suitable for restaurant or bar operators, are being created by the reconfiguration of two existing shops fronting Falcon Square.Burger King UK is the first operator to sign up while talks are ongoing with operators for the other units.In addition, a new kiosk will be created fronting the Falcon Square mall entrance. Possible uses include an outlet for a food takeaway.The development comes as the cityrsquos nearby rail station is set to undergo a pound million upgrade while a public consultation is currently ongoing into a bold vision to transform Academy Street to make it more pedestrian-friendly.Alasdair Murdoch, chief executive of Burger King UK, said: ldquoWe are excited to expand the Burger King brand in Inverness and look forward to welcoming guests to experience the great-tasting, high-quality food that has delighted Burger King customers for  years.Local building and construction company Compass expects to hand over the units in late May to be fitted out and managing director Thom Macleod is delighted it has been appointed principal contractor for the redevelopment of the former Monsoon and Mamas and Papas unit.ldquoHaving been involved extensively in the planning of the project, it is pleasing to now be making preparations for the works to get formally under way on site, he said.Previous proposals involved an extension into Falcon Square or rooftop bar but were altered to attract a wider range of operators.Centre manager Jackie Cuddy said it will be business usual while work proceeds.ldquoWe are delighted to see the works progressing after several enforced delays over the yearsshe said. ldquoThe market may have changed since we first started out on this journey but we are still optimistic that we can provide a great addition to the night time economy of Inverness with this development.Wednesday  Jan  : AM

title: aberdeen ease past stenhousemuir 4 1 in scottish cup replay
story: Aberdeen moved into the fth round of the Scottish Cup with a clinical - defeat of League One Stenhousemuir in a replay at Ochilview.Cheered on by a ,-strong travelling support, Aberdeen ruthlessly dispatched the side rock bottom of Scotland#s third tier.The Reds were - up a the break courtesy of goals from Niall McGinn, Sam Cosgroveand Greg Stewart, his first for the club since arriving back on loan until the end of the season from Birmingham.Stenhousemuir netted early in the second half through Andy Munro but there was never any chance of a replay of the Ochilview side#s infamous - Scottish Cup defeat of Aberdeen in .The Dons made three changes to the side that drew - with Kilmarnock in the league at the weekend.One change was enforced with Scotland international defender Scott McKenna ruled out with a hamstring injury sustained against Killie.On-loan Watford defender Tommie Hoban came in to replace McKenna.It was Hoban#s first start for the Dons since a - draw with Hibs in late August.Hoban suffered a shoulder injury in that match at Easter Road that required surgery and ruled him out for five months.Scott Wright and Niall McGinn ed to the starting line-up with Gary Mackay-Steven and Stevie May dropping to the bench.Aberdeen created the first opportunity in the fth minute when Lewis Ferguson fired in a powerful drive from  yards that keeper Graeme Smith ed to his right to parry,The loose ball fell to the onrushing McGinn, but his -yard shot slammed into the side netting.However, the Northern Ireland international winger would not miss when presented with another chance soon after.Recalled to the starting line-up winger Scott Wright broke into the penalty area at pace and stepped past two challenges before squaring a pass to McGINN, who fired a low clinical drive beyond Smith.In the th minute the lively Wright drilled in a low shot from the left flank from  yards that flashed inches wide.Moments later skipper Graeme Shinne#s -yard effort took a deflection that sent it spinning inches wide of the Stenny far post with keeper Smith beaten.An inevitable second goal arrived on the half hour when Stewart was clumsily brought down in the box as he attempted to race onto a Shinnie pass that deflected off Conor McBrearty.Referee Barry Cook had no hesitation in pointing to the penalty spot.Prolic striker Sam COSGROVE stepped up and confidently slotted low to the keeper#s right for his th goal of the season.It was - in the th minute when Shinnie found STEWART with a through ball,The -year-old collected the pass, beat his man on the left,  then superbly chipped a shot over Smith from  yards out.In the th minute Stewart was denied another when Smith blocked his powerful long-range drive.Moments later keeper Joe Lewis was called into action for the first time when he ed to his right to tip a vicious drive from Mark Ferry behind for a corner.Aberdeen failed to clear the resultant corner and Andy MUNRO jumped highest at the  near post to header in from close range. It was sloppy from Aberdeen.It was - in the th minute when a cross from Stewart led to an attempted clearance from Ruaridh DONALDSON which rattled off the cross-bar and over the line for an own goal.In the th minute keeper Smith blocked a Cosgrove shot at close range then recovered quickly to also deny Wright.Aberdeen will now meet Queen of the South in the fth round at Pittodrie on February .ABERDEEN: Lewis, Logan, Hoban, Considine, Lowe, Ferguson, Shinnie, Wright, McGinn, Stewart, Cosgrove.Subs: Mackay-Steven , Wilson .Subs not used: Cerny, Ball, Gleeson, Ross, May.STENHOUSEMUIR: Smith, Duthie, Munro, Donaldson, Reid, Dickson, McBrearty, Ferry, Cook, Halleran, McGuigan.Subs:Subs not used: McGinn, Garcia Tena, Paterson, McMenamin, Gibbons.

title: young dons paired with gers in youth cup last four
story: Aberdeen have been drawn at home to Rangers in the Scottish Youth Cup semi-final.The Dons are scheduled to meet the Gers on Friday, February  in the last four of the competition for Under- teams.The young Reds beat Kilmarnock - last week in the quarter-final to reach this stage and are just  minutes from the Hampden final which will be played on Thursday, April .In the other semi-final Celtic will play Queen#s Park.

title: 119000 children in need cash boost for charlie house
story: An Aberdeen charity has been given a whopping £, in order to help children and babies with complex disabilities.Charlie House was awarded the six-figure sum, which will be paid out over three years, from the BBC’s Children In Need fund.Bosses at the charity said the incredible sum will “change the lives” of children across the north-east.Charlie House was founded in  and currently runs a number of services for youngsters with complex disabilities and or le-limiting conditions and their families.These include activity and siblings clubs, one-to-one support, annual adventure trips and a community nurse who works in hospitals.The funding will be used to provide therapeutic, supportive and fun activities for young people in order to allow siblings to better come to terms with their brother or sister’s le-limiting condition.It’s hoped that in turn will allow them to better manage their emotions, develop new friendships and experience a more positive home environment.Tracy Johnstone, chairwoman and founder of Charlie House, said: “We could not expand our reach to families and young people in the north-east of Scotland without the support of BBC Children In Need. This grant will go on to change the lives of so many young people and give them the support they need, when they need it.“This project support will improve the mental and emotional wellbeing of siblings of children with complex disabilities and le-limiting conditions by providing one-to-one and group or family therapeutic support, sibling support and pre-and post-bereavement support.”In November Charlie House announced its plans to build a specialist support centre based in four acres of ground at Woodend Hospital.Aimed at providing respite for families, it will also feature a number of dferent facilities, and will be the first of its kind in the north-east.At present, people have to travel more than  miles to the nearest respite centre, which is in Kinross.In the north-east alone, there are more than , babies, children and young people with complex disabilities.The Big Build Appeal aims to raise £ million, which will allow the construction and maintenance of the building.It will comprise eight children’s bedrooms with accompanying family accommodation, and will also have flexible office and meeting space for employees.Florence Burke, national head of Scotland at BBC Children In Need, said: “We are committed to improving the lives of those children and young people who need it most.“Our support to Charlie House will enable them to make real and lasting changes to children with le-limiting conditions and their families across the north-east of Scotland. To quote Charlie House, le is precious, we believe that it should also be full of fun and friendship and look forward to seeing this funding in action.”BBC Children In Need has raised more than £ billion for children and young people across the UK.It supports more than , projects for those facing a range of disadvantages, including living in poverty, being disabled or ill, or experiencing distress, neglect or trauma. To help with the fundraising, donate online by visiting bit.ly ROBktF or call the Charlie House office on  .To find out more about how to support the Big Build Appeal contact the charity at bigbuild@charliehouse.org.uk

title: aberdeen schoolboy to take part in european youth parliament
story: A north-east student is representing Aberdeen at the European Parliament.Ross Mennie, , an S student at Cults Academy, left for Strasbourg on Sunday to represent the school as part of a European Youth Parliament programme.He is one of  young students from Scotland who made the journey to the official seat of the European parliament.They will be treated as MEPs and debate important issues affecting young people in the EU.Ross said: “I couldn’t believe it when they told me about the opportunity to go to Strasbourg.“I hope to improve my French and learn more about politics as I have received unconditional offers to study at university in France.”

title: its official north east ceilidh band named worlds largest
story: Hundreds of north-east people have entered the record books after being part of the world’s largest ceilidh band.The record was broken at Stonehaven Folk Festival last year and featured  musicians and dancers, including Aberdeenshire’s Lord Provost Bill Howatson.Everyone who took part had an agonizing six-month wait for the record attempt to be confirmed by Guinness World Records.Months of preparation had taken place in order for the event to go ahead, with people trying to gain members from wherever possible.Organiser Liz Johnstone said it took months to organise the event and was so determined to recruit, that no musician was safe.She said: “I would accost people anywhere.“I was standing in a queue in Glasgow and spotted a woman carrying a violin case, so I asked hershe could play.#It turned out she was a member of the National Fiddle Orchestra.”Musicians attended from all over Scotland, mostly from Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire, but also England and even as far afield as the USA and Germany.There was the usual last minute panic, as T-shirts had been ordered both to identy the musicians and, cunningly, had music printed on the back to help the rows of players.But they didn’t arrive until literally minutes before the non-stop procession of tin whistles, guitars, bodhrans, banjos and fiddles appeared at the Mackie Academy school hall.Jubilation at a faultless performance by the -strong band was followed by frustration over the following months – new records aren’t declared official without stringent vetting of the evidence provided.Stonehaven Folk Festival secretary Meg Findlay said: “You can imagine how I felt when they came back to us in December asking for a list of names and instruments of all the participants.”So it is with a sense of triumph that the committee of the Stonehaven Folk Festival now declare themselves officially world-beating – and they have the certicate to prove it.

title: jobs lost as north east accountant goes bust
story: An award-winning accountancy firm has gone bust, with its founder and owner citing “challenging business conditions”.Faith Simpson Accountants has gone into liquidation, leaving five members of staff unemployed.The firm had offices in Elgin and Huntly until September, when the Moray branch closed, and now the Huntly office has also shut.Ms Simpson, who founded the business in , said it had been plagued by problems in recent months and struggled to bounce back after she had to take time off due to illness.She said: “Along with rising staff costs and challenging business conditions, the company faced challenges since I took some time to recover from illness a few years ago.“It is unfortunate, but in these uncertain times, we have struggled to persuade clients to raise their fees in line with our cost base and have also faced late payment which has meant the business has had to absorb these losses.”

title: possible traffic delays as aberdeens ultrafast broadband rollout continues
story: A number of Aberdeen roads are set to be closed to install ultrafast internet.The Cityfibre scheme is hoped to make Aberdeen the first city in Scotland to have web speeds of up to one gigabyte per second.As part of the scheme,  miles of cables have had to be placed under city streets.Some of the disruption caused by this work is now set to hit the Rosehill area of the city.Starting on February , roads in that area will face a series of partial closures.Morgan Road, Cairncry Avenue, Cairncry Terrace, Ash-hill Road, Cairncry Terrace and Ash-hill Drive are all facing partial closure until March .A subsequent batch of roads have also been earmarked for work.Ash-hill Place and Cornhill Drive are next on the list, with closures due toto Cairncry Terrace and Ash-hill Road before work ends on March .Along with the partial closures of the roads, a ban on parking will also be imposed on the affected streets between am on February  and pm on March .Aberdeen City Council has warned that any cars parked illegally will be removed and must be recovered at the expense of the owner.Meanwhile, Cityfibre is also set to shut down a street in the heart of the city centre.Exchange Street, between its junction with Trinity Lane and Guild Street, will be closed for the work between am on February  and February  at pm.The one-way restriction on Exchange Street will also be suspended during that period between the junction with Guild Street and Imperial Lane.

title: ayr blind swimmer takes water
story: NewsAyr blind swimmer takes to water to raise cash for charityAyr girl Fern Walker, will attempt more than  s over the coming weeks.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN NewsFern is splitting her charity swim between Prestwick and Troon pools "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA blind swimmer has taken to the water in a bid to raise charity cash. Ayr girl Fern Walker, will attempt more than  s over the coming weeks. The -year-old is putting in the aqua miles at her favourite pools in Prestwick and Troon in the hope of raising more than pound. Fern, who lives with Bardet-Biedl Syndrome , is completing the challenge with the aid of her care team at Partners For Inclusion. She said: “I really enjoy my swimming and I come to the pool three times a week. “It will be tough to complete all these s and I’ve just started out – but I’m enjoying it so far.” BBS is a rare genetic disorder with symptoms including sight loss, obesity and reduced kidney . Like many other sufferers, Fern was also born with extra digits. The condition affects just one in , people across the world.   Sister Leigh, , said: “We’re all incredible proud of Fern and what she’s trying to achieve. “She was diagnosed with BBS at a very young age and her condition, particularly her sight, has deteriorated through time. “But she is never one to complain so this is typical of her attitude – she’s just determined to get out there and do something worthwhile.” Staff at Prestwick and Troon pools are helping encourage Fern during her bid, as she tackles up to  s at a time during each session. And the former Mainholm Academy pupil hopes to complete the marathon water trip while stacking up the cash for BBS UK. The charity provides support for those living with the condition and their carers. Leigh added: “It would be niceFern’s story going public could help with her fundraising effort. “She has her small group of friends and carers but it would mean the world to her to get support from further afield and raise as much as she can.” •To donate visit https:www.justgiving fundraising fern-walker

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: caravan caught alight sparks major
story: NewsCaravan which caught alight sparks major fire operationThe derelict property on Kilmarnock Road in Monkton went up in flames last Thursday night as the caravan attached to it caught fire.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  JAN NewsThe fire spread to the adjacent property "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA caravan which caught alight sparked a large scale fire operation as it set ablaze to a neighbouring house. The derelict property on Kilmarnock Road in Monkton went up in flames last Thursday night as the caravan attached to it caught fire. Four fire engines raced to the scene to tackle the blaze. And an aerial appliance was also mobilised by Scottish Fire and Rescue service. Firefighters battled the flames well into the night . The road remained closed after pm, eyewitnesses said. And a fire engine stayed at the scene the following morning.   One eyewitness said: “The house was right up in smoke. It was a big fire and luckily they got it when they did or it could have been worse.” A Scottish Fire and Rescue spokesman said: “We were alerted at .pm on Thursday, January  to a fire involving a caravan attached to a derelict property in Monkton. “Operations Control mobilised four fire engines and an aerial appliance to the scene, on Kilmarnock Road, where crews extinguished the fire, which had partly spread to the adjacent property building. “There were no casualties. “A single fire engine remains at the scene this morningto ensure the area remains safe.”

title: coventry city signing michael rose
story: NewsCoventry City signing Michael Rose can be future Scotland star, says Ayr United boss Ian McCallThe Ayr United centre half has completed a pre contract switch to the Ricoh Arena and will join the Sky Blues in the summer.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsMichael Rose, left, in action for Ayr United "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIan McCall reckons Coventry have bagged themselves a future Scotland star in Michael Rose. The -year-old has inked a two-year-deal with the Sky Blues after agreeing pre contract terms. And the highly rated centre half will join the League One giants this summer. Rose will see out the season with Ayr United before completing his lucrative move south. And Somerset boss McCall reckons the defender could even go on to eclipse goal king Lawrence Shankland - who is wanted by a string of top English clubs. He told the Ayrshire Post: You never want to lose players but Im delighted for the boy on a personal level. Everyone talks about Lawrence but, in my opinion, Michael Rose could go on to achieve just as much -not more -he wants to.  He is that good a player and Ive no doubt he can be a future Scotland international. For my money hes been the best centre half in the Championship this season. Of course wed have loved to keep him, but we have to be realistic. Rose is one of a number of players to reinvent their careers under McCall following his failure to break through as a youth at Aberdeen. And McCall said: It is further proof to boys thatthey come here and develop themselves, they will get their reward. Michael is an outstanding player with a very bright future and we wish him all the best. The deal was done quickly and professionally by Coventry and it means Michael can now focus fully on the rest of the season with us.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr United FCForfar Athletic FCScotland football teamScotland Us football teamAyrAyr News
